description:
Celebrating the champion — Maurice Gee’s contribution to children’s literature, Join us for a panel presentation focusing on the children’s writing of Maurice Gee, the celebrated New Zealand writer who died in June of this year, aged 93.
Speakers: NZ’s Reading Ambassador Kate de Goldi, commentator and award-winning writer for children Claire Mabey, poet Anna Jackson, memoirist and poet Harry Ricketts, and scholars Dr Tatjana Schaefer and Dr Vivien van Rij. The discussion will be introduced by Emeritus Professor Kathryn Walls.
This free event is hosted jointly by the Friends of the Dorothy Neal White Collection and Victoria University’s International Institute of Modern Letters.
All are welcome. Light refreshments will be served.
Date: Tuesday 23 September 2025
Time: 5.30 – 7:00pm (approx.) We shall begin with tea and coffee; the presentation will begin at 6.00 pm.
Place: Floor 12, Rutherford House, Bunny Street, Wellington
Enquiries to : Kathryn.Walls@vuw.ac.nz

description:
SHARPENING AT THE HARBOURSIDE MARKET, Holy molly! And just like that a month races by! Jo and I will be sharpening at the Harbourside market this coming Sunday. Bring your knives, edged gardening equipment, scissors, axes in for a good sharpening. Drop them off and go for a shop, lots of lovley foods and coffee to choose from. You can stock up on your veggies as well. Please be aware we can sometimes have a bit of wait. Payment is by cash or bank deposit, as we don't have eftpos.
See you all on Sunday.

description:
Wednesday Morning Jewellery-making In 8 Weeks, This NEW block of morning classes is the best way for beginners to get into jewellery making in a lively, warm and friendly environment. It will run from Wednesday 17 September for 8 weeks until Wednesday 5 November from 10am - 12.30pm.

This class is mixed level, allowing beginners to work alongside advanced students.

Beginners start with basic ring making in copper or brass, students will learn measuring, texturing, shaping, cutting and soldering.

Then we move on to making a practice ring set with a cabochon stone (cabochon means it has a flat bottom and a smooth domed top).

Once your first setting is completed you can move to working in silver and produce another stone set ring with more interesting design elements.

Level 2 students explore chainmaking as a way to develop their fine soldering skills. Their silver project can be a pendant on a handmade chain or a piece of their own design.

Level 3 and above students are encouraged to work on their design skills and try new and challenging techniques.

Included in the class fee are:
Beginners: a materials pack that includes copper and brass for practising on, 2 gemstones and enough sterling and fine silver to complete the cabochon ring project.
Advanced: students receive a generous credit to spend on materials as they choose. All consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals are also included. Extra metals and materials are available for purchase in the studio.

Our booking system asks for full payment to be made via credit card, PayPal or AfterPay on booking. If you do not have access to these payment methods or need to pay your course fee over time please email us to arrange this.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Water Casting - Spring, This is a super quick 3-hour session, and is great fun to do with family or friends.
Water casting is a really hands-on low-tech casting method that results in surprising and fun little forms that can be turned into pendants with amazing textures and shapes.
You will be guided through melting silver and pouring it into water to create little charms.
Experiment with pouring at different heights to create different shapes.
Choose one or a few of your favourites to have drilled and turn into simple pendants or earrings, or new charms for your bracelets!
We will use hardened jump rings to attach your water-cast pieces to either colourful cord or you can choose sterling silver chains which you can purchase for extra.
The technique will be demonstrated with important health and safety practices, then students will be guided to do at least a couple of casts, and should expect to have at least one successful item to clean up and finish in the class.
A basic amount of metal allowance of a small amount of silver is included in your course costs, and if your projects go over that amount you can pay for the metal you use on the day via internet banking or cash.
This course is open to complete beginners and advanced makers. Extra materials such as chains and findings are available to purchase.
For health and safety reasons class participants must wear sturdy, closed toe shoes and have their hair tied back.
Workshop fee $128, Early bird $115 till 17 August.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery: More Catholic Tales (Nov 2025), Further Catholic Tales - new tour
Hear about a poet, a writer, soldiers and stories of Wellington history. Further Catholic Tales tells the stories of the wide range of people interred in the section known as Catholic 2.
The tour duration is 1 hour 30mins. The tour mostly follows paved surfaces but there are some areas of unevenness.

Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day by 9am by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

description:
Wellington Foraging for Wild Edible Weeds Workshop, Join Felicity of Wild Botanica for a wander around the edges of the Innermost Community gardens to learn about commonly found, wild, edible weeds. Build a relationship with a natural world that is overflowing with abundant, wild, edible, nutritious, medicinal plants. Learn their names & get to know them, along with folklore & stories from the past.

By the end of the workshop you will:
- understand the basic principles of foraging, including sustainable harvesting
- feel confident in identifying 10-15 wild edible plants
- know about their nutritional & medicinal benefits
- know about common toxic/dangerous plants to avoid when foraging
- know about the best ways to prepare your foraged greens for maximum nutritional benefit & flavor
- feel empowered to include foraged greens in your everyday diet

Walk away with hands on, practical skills & knowledge that you can use in your own life.

Investment includes hands on wild weed walk & discussion, cup of foraged herbal tea & wildly delicious foraged snack.

To learn more about Felicity and her offerings,
visit @wildbotanica.nz on social media
or www.wildbotanica.co.nz.
For any queries, please email felicity@wildbotanica.co.nz.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Wellington Foraging Workshop 30th August 2025, Join expert forager Felicity Joy of Wild Botanica for a Wild Edible Weeds Foraging Workshop in the beautiful community gardens of Mount Victoria, Wellington.
This inspiring experience will open your eyes to the abundance of edible wild plants growing right under your nose.
We’ll unlock the secrets of foraging, connecting with the land, and turning humble "weeds" into delicious, nourishing food. You’ll gain confidence in identifying common edible plants, learn their botanical names, and understand their medicinal and nutritional benefits. We’ll also explore ethical foraging practices, how to spot toxic lookalikes, and share simple, practical ways to incorporate wild foods into your daily meals.
This isn’t just about food—it’s about sustainability, resilience, and reconnecting with the environment in a meaningful way. You'll leave with a deeper appreciation for the land, new skills to support local food security, and the knowledge to make your own simple meals from wild ingredients.
Class sizes are limited, so book early to secure your spot.
For more details and bookings, visit
www.wildbotanica.co.nz
follow @wild.botanica.nz on social media.
For questions, email felicity@wildbotanica.co.nz.
Join my email newsletter to hear about upcoming foraging workshops: https://www.wildbotanica.co.nz/pages/newsletter
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Ōtari Raranga Weavers Hōngongoi 2025 - Beginners, Kua raranga tahi tātou he whariki mō āpōpō
Together we weave the mat for future generations

Nau mai haere mai, all are welcome to attend Ōtari Raranga wānanga (classes).

No experience required and all materials provided. You will walk away with woven taonga at the end of every class.

During the first 2 classes, beginner students will complete a variety of putiputi (flowers). We will teach you how to harvest for yourself during this time.
Moving forwards you will start making kōnae (2 corner kete - basket), kono (4 sided kete) and more. You will need to harvest 8-10 rau for yourself and start building your own tool kit.
After completing 6 or more beginner classes (close together) you may be ready to move up to our intermediate classes. Please talk with our kaiako and kaiāwhina if you are interested.

With regular attendance you will:
- Learn tikanga (protocols) and karakia for hauhake (harvesting) and preparing harakeke
- Build your mātauranga (knowledge)
- Use kupu Māori appropriate to raranga practice
- Develop your pūkenga (practical skills)
- Create taonga (treasures) for your whānau
- Build hononga (connections) within our raranga rōpū (group)
- Have the skills to practice at home.

What’s included in your beginners ticket?
- Three hour weaving class with experienced kaiako
- Harakeke is provided for your first two classes and then you should hauhake (harvest) for yourself.
- If you are unable to harvest for class, we have a $10 ‘Please harvest for me’ option in addition to your ticket at least two days before class.
- Light refreshments are provided and we encourage you to bring kai to share

Led by Linda Lee (Ngāti Huia, Ngāti Raukawa, Ngāti Kurī, Te Rarawa, Te Aupōuri), and Anna Lees (Te Āti Awa, Kāi Tahu), and on occasion our raranga rangatira; Frank Topia (Ngā Puhi, Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Haua), with support from our kaiāwhina; Anita Murdoch (Ngati Kahungunu, Waikato-Tainui), Sarah O’Sullivan (Ngāi Tahu), Te Kāhui Tapsell (Te Arawa, Tainui), and Frankie Stewart (Tangata Tiriti).

Important information
- It is important that everyone turns up on time for karakia

Together we weave the mat for future generations

Nau mai haere mai, all are welcome to attend Ōtari Raranga wānanga (classes).

No experience required and all materials provided. You will walk away with woven taonga at the end of every class.

During the first 2 classes, beginner students will complete a variety of putiputi (flowers). We will teach you how to harvest for yourself during this time.
Moving forwards you will start making kōnae (2 corner kete - basket), kono (4 sided kete) and more. You will need to harvest 8-10 rau for yourself and start building your own tool kit.
After completing 6 or more beginner classes (close together) you may be ready to move up to our intermediate classes. Please talk with our kaiako and kaiāwhina if you are interested.

With regular attendance you will:
- Learn tikanga (protocols) and karakia for hauhake (harvesting) and preparing harakeke
- Build your mātauranga (knowledge)
- Use kupu Māori appropriate to raranga practice
- Develop your pūkenga (practical skills)
- Create taonga (treasures) for your whānau
- Build hononga (connections) within our raranga rōpū (group)
- Have the skills to practice at home.

What’s included in your beginners ticket?
- Three hour weaving class with experienced kaiako
- Harakeke is provided for your first two classes and then you should hauhake (harvest) for yourself.
- If you are unable to harvest for class, we have a $10 ‘Please harvest for me’ option in addition to your ticket at least two days before class.
- Light refreshments are provided and we encourage you to bring kai to share

Led by Linda Lee (Ngāti Huia, Ngāti Raukawa, Ngāti Kurī, Te Rarawa, Te Aupōuri), and Anna Lees (Te Āti Awa, Kāi Tahu), and on occasion our raranga rangatira; Frank Topia (Ngā Puhi, Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Haua), with support from our kaiāwhina; Anita Murdoch (Ngati Kahungunu, Waikato-Tainui), Sarah O’Sullivan (Ngāi Tahu), Te Kāhui Tapsell (Te Arawa, Tainui), and Frankie Stewart (Tangata Tiriti).

Important information
- It is important that everyone turns up on time for karakia
- For tikanga purposes beginner ticket sales close two days before wānanga giving us time to hauhake (harvest) for you
- If class numbers are too low, we may have to cancel (and will offer a refund or transfer) so please check your emails before class

- We welcome children aged 10-14 but they should be accompanied by an adult with a ticket

description:
A Change Is Coming walk tour (Wellington Heritage Festival), A Change Is Coming walk tour (Wellington Heritage Festival)
1pm, SUNDAY 19th OCTOBER 2025

2025 marks the 40th anniversary of the introduction in 1985, of the Homosexual Law Reform bill. The bill set out to decriminalise homosexual activity between consenting adults and make it illegal to discriminate against someone based on their sexual orientation.

But this wasn’t the first attempt at homosexual law reform. Join us on this special 90-minute free walk tour to celebrate the people and movements that fought for a brighter future for rainbow communities.

Our journey begins at the location of the first public meeting in New Zealand, advocating for homosexual law reform in 1967. This was two years before the Stonewall uprising in the U.S. which went on to ignite Gay Liberation around the world.

The tour ends at Parliament, where we honour the Members of Parliament who have championed equality over the last five decades.

Along the way, we’ll reflect on some of the difficult realities rainbow communities have faced, from the injustices of the legal system, to the stances of the medical profession, churches and the military. As the late activist Ralph Knowles recalls, “As far as medicine was concerned, it was sick. As far as the law was concerned, it was a crime. As far as the church was concerned, it was a sin.”

Though at times the stories are challenging, this walk tour is ultimately uplifting, as we pay tribute to our amazing rainbow kaumatua and allies who led the way.

COST: Free, but please register so we can manage the number of walkers: https://walktoursnz.wordpress.com/book/

DATE/TIME: 1pm, Sunday 19th October 2025

STARTS: meet at the rugby sculpture, Jack Ilott Green, corner of Harris Street & Jervois Quay (just by Civic Square)

ENDS: Parliament grounds

DURATION: 1 hour 30mins

ACCESSIBILITY: the tour is on flat public footpaths, with a light incline as we enter Parliament grounds. Tours are limited to approximately 20 walkers.

This tour is part of the amazing Wellington Heritage Festival - https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz

description:
Art and AI: Brit Bunkley in Conversation with Megan Dunn, Art and AI: Brit Bunkley in Conversation with Megan Dunn
Artist and filmmaker Brit Bunkley discusses the pragmatics and politics of making art with AI. Join us for a discussion in the Gallery, with insights into the making of his latest work Archive, commissioned for Messengers.

--

Brit Bunkley is a New Zealand-based artist and videographer whose practice spans sculpture, installation, and digital media. A recipient of the US National Endowment for the Arts fellowship, two NY state grants, and the Rome Prize Fellowship, his work explores the intersection of physical and virtual spaces, often blending surreal imagery with themes of history, politics, and environmental concerns. He has exhibited at the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa and internationally at Rencontres Internationales Paris/Berlin, FILE São Paulo (including 2025), and the Athens Digital Arts Festival. Recent exhibitions include Visions in the Nunnery, London (2022), Cybersculpture 2024 at Collège des Bernardins, Paris, and The Torrance Art Museum, LA (2025). In 2024, he won Best Art | Experimental Video/Film at the New York City Independent Film Festival. His work continues to evolve, embracing new technologies and alternative methodologies to challenge perceptions of reality and imagination.

Learn more here > https://citygallery.org.nz/events/art-and-ai-brit-bunkley-in-conversation-with-megan-dunn/

IMAGE Brit Bunkley, still from Archive, single channel video, 2025

description:
Churton Park Toasmasters meeting, Would you like to improve your communication skills? Become a more confident public speaker? Grow your leadership skills? Meet new people?
Churton Park Toastmasters Club is just for you. We are multicultural, supportive, a friendly fun club where you can lose that fear of public speaking and improve your confidence, communication and leadership skills.
We meet on Thursdays every fortnight. The meeting will be held at the Johnsonville Bowling Club (34 Frankmoore Avenue, Johnsonville). Please arrive about 10 minutes earlier so that we can meet and explain how the meeting is organised.
We welcome guests to any of our meetings. There is no pressure to participate and you can just observe. Come visit us and meet our dynamic and diverse group. We're sure you will enjoy your time at the meeting!

description:
Wellington Motogymkhana, Wondered what Moto Gymkhana is?
Keen to build confidence on your bike and improve your handling skills?
One of the hundred people who have "always been meaning to check it out"? Then this Thursday is your night! Come join us at the Tawa Outlet Mall for an evening of Motogymkhana.
All skill levels are welcome. We've designed beginner course for the summer, that isn't too technical and is a good introduction to the sport. (We've even tested it with a new rider!) And if anyone is struggling, we have a group of well-practiced riders to give you some pointers and help you out. Our only expectation is you're confident to ride on the road. The rest should come with a little bit of Thursday night practice.
If you're not comfortable doing it on your own pride and joy, there are club bikes that can be rented for the night. We just ask for a donation to help us cover rent, fuel and broken levers.
Unfortunately, due to changes in our circumstances this year, we're a little short on cash-flow, and are asking for a gold-coin donation from anyone riding to help keep the lights on.

description:
Asia After Five: Experiences in Taiwan, About the event
The Asia New Zealand Foundation and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office Wellington are hosting an evening of stories and insights from New Zealanders who have studied, worked and lived in Taiwan. Hear from the Foundation's Leadership Network members and Taiwan alumni as they share their experiences and reflect on future opportunities for Kiwis in Taiwan.
Our Asia After Five events are interactive. You will have a chance to ask questions, network with others and learn more about Asia.
Event details
Date:  Thursday 25 September 2025
Time:  5:30pm-7:00pm
Venue:  Asia New Zealand Foundation, Level 16, Fujitsu Tower, 141 The Terrace (access to building via Cable Car Lane before 6pm)
This event is free to attend, but please RSVP for catering purposes.
This event is a collaboration between the Asia New Zealand Foundation Te Whītau Tūhono and Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New Zealand (TECO).
Our speakers
Ema Kato
Ema Kato is a recent graduate from Victoria University of Wellington with a degree in Communication, specialising in intercultural communication and Mandarin. Having lived in Japan, Taiwan and New Zealand, Ema is passionate about cross-cultural exchange and will return to Taiwan next year to pursue advanced language study and a master’s program at National Taiwan University with the Huayu and Taiwan Scholarships.
Tom Durkin
Tom is currently based in Auckland, working in Private Wealth at Craigs Investment Partners. Having studied Mandarin as a part of his degree at the University of Otago, he has long held an interest in Chinese language and culture. Tom spent two months travelling in Taiwan at the end of 2023. During this time, he joined parts of the Taipei Hui with the Asia New Zealand Foundation Leadership Network, worked with a farmer in Chiayi and spent two weeks at Fo Guang Shan Buddhist monastery in Southern Taiwan. His participation in the recent Shanghai Hui with the Asia New Zealand Leadership Network sparked a desire to re-engage and immerse in Chinese culture. Tom has recently been accepted to study at the National Taiwan Normal University - Mandarin Training Center from later this year. He's looking forward to sharing his experiences and hearing more on others' perspectives of the New Zealand-Taiwan relationship.
Lauren Pattermore
Lauren Pattemore is an early-career journalist based in New Zealand, with contributions to Stuff, the Otago Daily Times, Crux and Radio New Zealand. She recently completed a media internship with the Asia New Zealand Foundation in Taipei, working with TaiwanPlus. In 2024, she was named runner-up for Best Up and Coming Journalist at the Voyager Media Awards. She holds a Bachelor of Communication from Massey University, where she specialised in expressive arts and journalism.
Rob Eland
Rob was the sole New Zealand recipient of the Taipei City Chinese Learning Scholarship in 2018, selected by Mayor Justin Lester. With the scholarship, he took a sabbatical from work and travelled to Taipei, where he lived from mid-2018 to early 2019. During this time, Rob studied full-immersion Chinese at NTNU's Mandarin Training Center (MTC) and took part in several New Zealand–Taiwan cross-cultural activities, including supporting then-Deputy Mayor Jill Day and a group of New Zealand performing arts students during their visit to Taiwan. Rob returned to New Zealand in 2019, but he looks forward to heading back to Taiwan again soon.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Intro to Musical Improv | A PopRox Improv Course, Musical improv can be absolute magic. Whether it's a whole musical show, or single song that bursts out of an emotional scene, music adds so much to our improv.
This course for improvisers will give an introduction to musical improv. We'll cover basic song structures, how to get into a song from a scene, how to support a song through chorus work, and why and when we use music to add to our improv.
Participants should be confident in scene-work and have at least 2 years improv experience. This course will not teach you how to approach scenes and characters, so you should have a solid foundation which you can add to with this new toolbox of musical skills.
The course includes 6 workshops which will run 6:30pm to 8:30pm on Wednesdays from August 6th to September 10th. As it is an intro course, we do not anticipate a showcase for this course.
ABOUT THE TEACHERS
LIA KELLY is a theatre-maker and teacher based in Pōneke. She is an established director, actor, improviser and musician and has been a part of productions across the city over the last 10 years. She directed One Night Band which won 'Most Original Production' at the Wellington Theatre Awards 2023, and performs regularly as both a player and musician for POPROX.
ISAAC THOMAS has been an improviser and improv musician for a decade in Pōneke and Whakatū/Nelson. He's played with Body in Space, Playshop, Poprox and been musical director for musical improv powerhouse The Pāua Ballads. He has worked with almost every major improv company around the city accompanying them through improvised piano, guitar and vocals.
THE STANDY-BY LIST
PopRox firmly believes that improv is for everyone, especially when it comes to sharing skills and knowledge. So we're offering "the stand-by list" for all our workshops in 2025. We'll giveaway any spots remaining a few days before the first workshop of the course, on a first-come-first-serve basis. No need to provide a reason, no questions asked. If the entry fee is a barrier for you to come along, then simply email poproximprov@gmail.com and we'll pop you on the SBL. Everyone on the list will be notified whether there was a place available for them 3 days before the first workshop.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Bride Of The Year 2025, For 55 years, Wairarapa Bride of the Year has been a mainstay in the events calendar in the region. The event returns to the Wairarapa Events Centre for 2025, where brides who were married between 1 July and 30 June and were married in the Wairarapa, and/or have lived or are living in the Wairarapa, and/or whose spouse has lived in the Wairarapa, will get the chance to relive the magic of their big day, donning their gowns again, all while raising much needed funds for Te Awhina Plunket Wairarapa.

This event is unique in its focus on Wairarapa’s flourishing wedding industry. It is a great opportunity for couples planning their own weddings to look for inspiration from other local couples, for friends and families of brides to reminisce on the weddings. It is also an excellent opportunity to support Wairarapa Plunket and the service they provide to our community.

In 2024, the funds raised through Bride of the Year went towards purchasing equipment for use for Plunket rooms across Wairarapa along with purchase .

A ticket to Bride of the Year provides you with a night of glamour and celebration of love, all while supporting Wairarapa Plunket and the service they provide to our community.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Fight Knight, Brace yourself — on Thursday 16th October, our axe lanes morph into a bone-rattling, armor-clanking cage of chaos! Watch as trained warriors clad in gleaming medieval armor unleash flying axes and clashing swords in a battle for ultimate bragging rights.

This isn’t your average Thursday night — it’s epic sword-swinging, axe-chopping, heart-pounding theatre you’ve gotta see to believe. Feel the thunder of steel, the roar of the crowd, and the thrill of knights battling for glory.

Whether you’re cheering from the sidelines or planning your own medieval takeover, this is THE event where legends are born and legends are made.
label: Sports & Fitness

description:
Are You Smarter Than A Drag Queen? - A Drag Trivia Night ( WELLINGTON ), Join Rosa Violeta and Yuri Guaii, star of RuPaul’s Drag Race Down Under and The Boulet Brothers’ Dragula, as we finally answer the age-old question: Are You Smarter Than a Drag Queen?

This is a trivia night unlike any other.. packed with fabulous prizes, outrageous drag shows, chaotic banter, and questions that’ll have you questioning everything.
Grab your smartest (or stupidest) friends and head to Saint Diablo in Wellington on October 24rd for a night of camp, cocktails, and competition. Expect stunning looks, unhinged lip-syncs, and maybe even a heated debate over who really invented the Pavlova.
Think you’ve got what it takes to win? There’ll be prizes, bragging rights, and chaotic glory up for grabs and not just for the trivia champs. Whether you nail the answers or charm your way through the madness, you might just walk away with something fabulous… or hilariously useless.
Tickets are $35 per person excl ticketing fees - 6:30PM to 9:00PM.
Seats are limited, so snatch yours now and don’t miss the most glamorous quiz night of the season!
For enquiries please contact Rosa Violeta at therosavioleta@gmail.com
DUNEDIN - OCTOBER 21ST - WOOF!
QUEENSTOWN - OCTOBER 22ND - SEARCHLIGHT BREWERY
CHRISTCHURCH - OCTOBER 23RD - MUY MUY
WELLINGTON - OCTOBER 24TH - SAINT DIABLO
label: Community & Culture

description:
CHAPPELL vs CHARLI: A Drag Fundraiser Smackdown, Friday 27 September | 9.30pm @ Ivy Bar, Pōneke
Tickets: $20 (excluding ticket fees) | Generosity options available!
All proceeds to Wellington Pride Festival!

Kia ora! brats and popstars! Get your heads out the passenger seat and get ready, cause your about to be bumpin’ that with some of wellington drags finest!
Royalty is stepping into the ring (well, the stage) for CHAPPELL vs CHARLI : a high-camp, high-stakes, drag smackdown showdown, where our fabulous local drag artists channel the icons of Charli XCX and Chappell Roan to battle it out for title of 'Queen of the Chartsverse'… all in the name of charity xx

Three lip sync rounds. Four drag titans. One glitter-drenched champion.
Each round sees performers pull a mystery song each from their assigned diva’s discography and fight for the crown based on lip sync accuracy and undeniable star quality. Think charity boxing... but queerer. Like, much queerer. Only you! The audience! And our incredible judge Rachel Winter Hase, can determine our number #1 pop icon!

Featuring:
- Homer Neurotic (multi-award-winning drag king)
- Slay West (the biggest mouth in the biz)
- Petra Fyde (now your petrified)
- Ms. Leading (Your big bros lil secret)
(and Olivia Dreams on door)

Hosted by the ever-glamorous Selina Simone, and judged by local performance legend Rachel Winter Hase, who will deliver her pop verdicts with love and lashes *whipcrack.mp3

A high-speed crash of glitter, vocals, and vengeance! Expect drag, drama, and come ready to holler, hoot, bump and help decide who is our ultimate XCX BRAT or CHAPPELL POPSTAR!

Tickets: Just $20 + fees, with donation options for those feeling generous – every cent raised goes to support Wellington Pride Festival, helping make 2025 the queerest yet!

Accessibility: Ivy Bar is located downstairs but alternative access is possible with prior planning. Please email theselinasimone@gmail.com so we can accommodate you. If you wish to attend and donate, but cost is an issue for you, please reach to me as well xx

description:
Santa Cipolla, “Holy Onion”. For the entire month, Cicio Cacio Osteria is getting brave and bold, celebrating the magic of vegetables in all their glory, especially the santa cipolla (aka the holy onion). 
Vegetables bring colour, life and joy. In Italy, they mark the rhythm of the seasons, stir up cherished memories and signal the excitement of fresh beginnings. Come along and experience vibrant flavours with playful snacks, fun street food, freshly baked breads, handmade pasta and a brand new range of dishes that celebrate the beauty, bounty and simplicity of Italian cuisine.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Bride Of The Year 2025, For 55 years, Wairarapa Bride of the Year has been a mainstay in the events calendar in the region. The event returns to the Wairarapa Events Centre for 2025, where brides who were married between 1 July and 30 June and were married in the Wairarapa, and/or have lived or are living in the Wairarapa, and/or whose spouse has lived in the Wairarapa, will get the chance to relive the magic of their big day, donning their gowns again, all while raising much needed funds for Te Awhina Plunket Wairarapa.

This event is unique in its focus on Wairarapa’s flourishing wedding industry. It is a great opportunity for couples planning their own weddings to look for inspiration from other local couples, for friends and families of brides to reminisce on the weddings. It is also an excellent opportunity to support Wairarapa Plunket and the service they provide to our community.

In 2024, the funds raised through Bride of the Year went towards purchasing equipment for use for Plunket rooms across Wairarapa along with purchase .

A ticket to Bride of the Year provides you with a night of glamour and celebration of love, all while supporting Wairarapa Plunket and the service they provide to our community.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Celebrating 132 years of women’s suffrage — special lunchtime tour and kōrero, Join our kaimahi for a special lunchtime tour and kōrero, highlighting the 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition | Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine, which paved the way for women’s suffrage in Aotearoa.
Tour and kōrero
Mark your calendars for 19 September, the anniversary of the 1893 Electoral Act that granted New Zealand women the right to vote in parliamentary elections.
To celebrate Suffrage Day, join a 45-minute kōrero and tour of the 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition — Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine.
Tours are open to visitors of all ages (age 6+). Booking is not required.
Please meet at our waka reception desk on the ground floor before the start of the tour.
The ongoing struggle for equal rights
Come along to the National Library to learn about the journey New Zealand women took to gain the right to vote and about the ongoing struggle for equal rights.
View the 1893 petition that led to the creation of the Electoral Act 1893, which was signed into law on 19 September 1893.
Hear stories about wāhine toa like Meri Te Tai Mangakāhia (Te Rarawa) and suffragists Kate Sheppard, Ada Wells and maybe an ancestor of your own.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Kapiti Tattoo & Arts Festival 2026, Kapiti Tattoo & Arts Festival 2026
Get ready, Kapiti – something bold, creative, and totally unforgettable is coming your way. On Saturday, 7th March 2026, the Kapiti Tattoo & Arts Festival makes its explosive return at the Paraparaumu Memorial Hall, bringing together the ultimate fusion of ink, art, and live entertainment for one epic day of creativity and connection. Whether you're a tattoo enthusiast, an art lover, or someone who thrives in high-energy, artistic environments, this festival is your ticket to something truly extraordinary.

This isn’t just another tattoo expo — it’s a full-blown creative takeover. Expect to see over 40 talented artists under one roof, from the regions leading tattooists to visionary painters, sculptors, illustrators, and local craftspeople. You’ll witness live tattooing, explore interactive art installations, shop handcrafted works, and dive into workshops designed to spark your imagination. Plus, with non-stop local entertainment on the main stage — from musicians to performers and DJs — the atmosphere will be electric from start to finish.

What makes this event truly special? It’s powered by the team at Kapiti Castles — the creative minds behind the popular Kapiti Wedding & Events Expo. Known for producing vibrant, community-driven experiences, Kapiti Castles has crafted this festival as a platform for creative expression, community connection, and artistic inspiration. Whether you're an artist looking to grow your brand or a visitor eager to explore the region’s creative heartbeat, this is your moment.

The Kapiti Tattoo & Arts Festival is more than an event — it’s a movement. It’s a chance to meet incredible artists, get inspired, celebrate culture, and maybe even walk away with some fresh ink. With something for everyone — from art collectors to curious newcomers — this is a must-attend event for 2026.

So mark your calendars for 7th March, gather your crew, and get your tickets now. The Kapiti Tattoo & Arts Festival 2026 is where creativity comes alive, and you won’t want to miss being part of it. Tickets are on sale now — don’t miss your chance to be part of Kapiti’s boldest new festival.
label: Festivals

description:
CUBAN☆FUSION's Annualish PINK Cuba St Salsa Party Breast Cancer Fundraiser's 9th Anniversary - KOHA, CUBAN☆FUSION's Annualish PINK Cuba St Salsa Party Breast Cancer Fundraiser's 9th Anniversary - KOHA
On the 9th of October it will sadly be 9 years since our little sister Wilhelmina died of a particularly aggressive form of breast cancer just 3 weeks short of her 50th birthday and a week before her eldest of 4 girls' 16th birthday, which we bought forward a week so she could be there to celebrate it. She took her last breath at 6.06pm the next day while our father (RIP) and I held her hands and my brother played his guitar at her feet.. with Charles Humphreys at her head and our Mum and her girls looking on, and while Rafael and Sjaak held the fort and kicked off Sunday Salsa at The Cross.. in my absence.

***

PLEASE JOIN US DRESSED IN AS MUCH PINK AS POSSIBLE IN CUBA MALL ON FRIDAY 1 NOVEMBER @ 6PM - THE DAY BEFORE OUR SISTER'S ("MINA'") WOULD HAVE BEEN 58TH BIRTHDAY - TO CELEBRATE LIFE IN PINK 🩷 LA VITA IN ROSA 🩷 LEVEN IN ROZE 🩷 LA VIDA EN ROSA 🩷 LA VIE EN ROSE 🩷 ORA I ROTO I TE MAWHERO 🩷 AND TO RAISE AS MUCH AS WE CAN FOR BCFNZ.

***

CUBAN☆FUSION - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists' famous Cuba Street Salsa Party is going PINK this November for a very good cause - The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ.

What better place to dance Salsa than in the street, Cuba Street to be exact.

Don't worry if you don't know how to dance, we'll teach you!

Dress Code: PINK!

Help us raise awareness and funds for a very good cause and have a good time at the same time.. the Cuban way.. dancing the night away under the stars!

Suggested Koha/Donation: $5

Aiming to fund-raise $1,000 this year.. that's only 200 people @ $5 dancing Salsa in Cuba Street all PINKed up. We can do it!

EFTPOS available - 1.1% surcharge applies.

Alternatively, (or if you can't make it to the event, but would like to contribute) you can also donate on-line to our dedicated Pink Party account:

02-0343-0003801-007

ALL donations will go directly to The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ to help them in their mission to educate and find better cures.

Please give generously.

LOCATION: You will find us in "La Plaza" - the open space between the Bucket Fountain and the Left Bank Lane in Cuba Mall.

NB: This event is weather dependent. Decision to relocate or postpone will be made by 4pm at the latest on the day.

RAIN DATE: TBC

***

This event annualish (thanks to COVID) is dedicated to the memory of CUBAN☆FUSION's Co-Founder Rosina van der Aa's little sister Wilhelmina van der Aa, who died three weeks short of her 50th birthday on 9 October 2016 of very aggressive secondary breast cancer leaving behind four gorgeous girls and one loving husband.

#because_we_need_a_cure_not_a_miracle
#dontwalkby
#takeaction
#donate
#dancesalsa
#wearpink
#keepcalmdancecuban

Today 8 women will be diagnosed with Breast Cancer

Yet 30% of eligible women are not enrolled for free screening

This year 600+ will most likely die from Breast Cancer

And 60% of women do not know the signs beyond a lump

Knowledge is power… and knowledge helps beat breast cancer. Get knowledgeable here: https://www.breastcancerfoundation.org.nz/breast-awareness

Remember if you are 45-69 and not enrolled for free mammograms you can enrol by calling BreastScreen Aotearoa on 0800 270 200.

To find out more about CUBAN☆FUSION, its dance classes and upcoming dance and music event please visit our website.

CUBAN☆FUSION © 2005 - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists | www.cubanfusion.co.nz | | 021-621-245

description:
Cohousing in Wellington? Let’s Make It Happen, Circle Living is creating a new story for housing in Aotearoa - building intergenerational cohousing neighbourhoods where people can live more connected lives.
After successfully completing a 34-home cohousing neighbourhood in Tākaka, we’re now exploring the option of bringing cohousing to Wellington. We’d love for you to be part of the conversation.
Join us for an evening of ideas, connection, and opportunity.
📅 Tuesday 7 October 2025
🕠 5:30pm – 6:30pm
📍Creative HQ, Level 1, 7 Dixon Street, Wellington
Tickets are FREE but please sign up as it helps with planning. Nibbles and drinks provided.
✨ Learn about Circle Living and our vision for future cohousing neighbourhoods
✨ Hear what makes cohousing different (and why it matters)
✨ Explore how a Wellington development could look - and register your interest
✨ Find out about our equity crowdfunding campaign via PledgeMe and how you can own a share in our company
✨ Meet others who are curious about living - and investing - differently
Register now and help shape what’s possible with Circle Living.
label: Community & Culture

description:
The Merry-Go-Round Vintage Wares x Herb's Mobile Record Store @ The Wharehaus, We've missed The Merry-go-round's Alicetown bricks-and-mortar shop and it's been a while since we've seen physical music being sold in the Eastern suburbs so we're getting together to put on a collaborative pop-up on the 20th of this month.
These two are masters at curating the weird, obscure and wonderful - vintage bits, furniture, vinyl, cassettes, CD's, tees and retro gaming consoles.
Get along it'll be a blast.

description:
DEBRA NZ Conference and Family Camp 2025, Kia ora DEBRA New Zealand whanau !
Save the dates - DEBRA NZ Conference and Family Camp, Wellington, Friday 22 - Sunday 24 August 2025.
We are very happy to announce that we are planning a get-together for the NZ EB whanau and a few Aussie families in Wellington in August. We really hope you can join us - it will be wonderful to see you!
This event is a great opportunity to meet other families, connect with old friends and make wonderful new ones, learn from each other and from valuable talks about EB issues, and have time to relax and enjoy a couple of days in Wellington city - the creative capital! We're keen to hear about any particular topics you would like to hear about.
Everyone is welcome including extended family and friends, caregivers, and healthcare professionals.
Dates: Friday 22nd August (check-in from 3pm with informal meet and greet from 5.00pm), to Sunday 24th August (finishing 2pm after a farewell lunch)
Event location: Wellington City, venue to be confirmed
Registration will be launched in early May - please stay tuned for further details!
Your registration fee will cover the conference, meals and children’s activities from Friday evening to Sunday lunch time, but it does not cover accommodation (amount to be confirmed), travel or airport transfers.
DEBRA NZ will provide some limited assistance with accommodation and travel costs if needed, subsiding flights for the person attending with EB.
Please contact debra@debra.org.nz if you would like to apply for this support.
There will be more information soon.
We need an idea of numbers so please get in touch as soon as possible!
Email: debra@debra.org.nz with any questions and let us know if you are interested in attending.
Nga mihi nui,
Anna, Lea and the DEBRA NZ team
debra@debra.org.nz
label: Community & Culture

description:
Creative Futures: Arts, Economy and System Shifts, Join celebrated artist and cultural leader Teremoana Rapley MNZM for a powerful wānanga exploring the role of creativity in shaping local economies and systems. From local identity and wellbeing to economic growth and policy influence, this workshop invites artists, community leaders, and changemakers to reimagine the power of the arts in our region.
Through kōrero and shared storytelling, we’ll unpack how artistic practice can drive systems change and strengthen Lower Hutt's inclusive, culturally rich creative economy, one that reflects indigenous and local voices of communities across Te Awa Kairangi.
Teremoana Rapley MNZM is a pioneering artist, broadcaster, and cultural leader whose work spans music, television, and indigenous creative advocacy. Of Kiribati, Rarotonga, Aitutaki, Mangaia, Cuba, Jamaica, and Suriname descent, she first rose to prominence with Upper Hutt Posse and Moana & the Moahunters. Her practice is rooted in indigenous storytelling, systems change, and mentoring, often acting as a “Matriarchitect” to uplift others. With accolades including the Pacific Music Awards Lifetime Achievement Award and induction into the Aotearoa Music Hall of Fame, Rapley continues to shape Aotearoa’s creative landscape through collaboration, education, and community engagement.
In partnership with Toi Rauwhārangi College of Creative Arts, Massey University.
Light refreshments provided.
label: Community & Culture

description:
DRAG BINGO with Selina Simone! @DLS, Darling, This is not your grandma's Bingo! this is DRAG BINGO with local drag artist, ya dad's favorite, sinner & showgirl, SELINA SIMONE!
Brace yourself for an evening dripping with glamour, sparkle, and a whole lot of cheek as you soak in the skyline of Wellington's most unique rooftop hideaway
DIRTY LITTLE SECRET!
Slip into something fabulous, grab your favorite drink, and get ready for an extravagant night of DRAG BINGO! We've got cocktails that'll make you blush, and more laughs than you can shake a feather boa at!
Expect live drag performances to make your heart race, dad jokes that'll have you in stitches, and beats from our fabulous local DJs that'll keep you moving all night long! Book your table for 7.00pm, balls dropping 7.30 at the latest!
Event Highlights:
Hold onto your wigs, honey, because it's FREE to enter! And we have well over $200 worth of PRIZES to be won! including our grand prize... $100.00 BAR VOUCHER! odds not in your favour? we have SPOT PRIZES up for grabs, so sexy naughty and fun I'm not allowed to mention them on this media platform!
Oh, and speaking of keeping things alive, why not order a bit of me with the "Selina Simone" cocktail? Curious about how I taste? One sip, and you'll be hooked! Check out our epic kai offers as well!
Get your gang together, you've got to book a table to secure your spot! let's turn this night into a campy, sexy extravaganza!
Reserve your table for 7:00 pm, bookings are hot, so snatch yours now through the link below (or the ticket link on this page) https://dirtylittlesecret.co.nz/events/drag-bingo/ Limited Walk-In's on the night
xx
Immerse yourself in enchanting breathtaking views that will elevate your experience. From the glittering city lights to the stars above, DIRTY LITTLE SECRET is Wellington's most unique rooftop bar, offering a setting as sensational as the entertainment!
But wait, the fun doesn't stop there! Our sensational DJ will be spinning tunes from around 9/9:30 pm 'til late. Let's keep the dance floor sizzling and the party vibes alive!
For our guests with specific accessibility needs, we have elevator access to ensure everyone can join in on the fun. However, as some tables are on raised bits of flooring, we encourage those with accessibility requirements to reach out to us directly. Your comfort is our priority, and we're here to make sure your night is as fabulous as can be!
LGBTQIA+ Friendly: Our staff and security at Dirty Little Secret are not just friendly; they're fabulous! Trained to meet the needs of all our diverse patrons, ensuring a safe, and welcoming space for everyone xx
TRIGGER WARNINGS: This is an R18 event! Expect strong language, good vibes, and thotty danger and legs so smooth they'll sweep you off your feet!—100% guaranteed! xx

description:
Wednesday Disc-ruption GLOW, @ Berhampore #35 (mix of short and long tees), Join the Discruption team for a Glow Disc Golf round at Berhampore golf course Wednesday night.
Mix of long and shorts;
Round 1: All shorts
Round 2: Long tees for 1, 3,4,5 & 6
Round 3: All shorts
Follow U-Disc for teepad locations if in doubt - course layout has been updated for this event.
Teepad lighting predominantly on the shorts since these present more of a tripping hazard in the dark.
Please bring your own glow discs and torches - you are welcome to the pool discs to borrow & return at the box.
Koha jar is also there if you would like to help with our expenses.
We'll be lighting it up from 6:30pm - 9.30pm. Bring your own card of 4 or make up a group with other players at regular teepad #1 at 630pm.
_____________________________
A U-Disc league event will be created for you to check into and keep track of your score.
Please remember to pay your green fees and of course bring a headtorch if you need it to navigate the course.
label: Sports & Fitness

description:
Diabetes NZ Nelson Youth: Marlborough Whānau Swim for Diabetes Action Month 2025!, Join Diabetes NZ Nelson Youth for an afternoon at Stadium 2000 in Blenheim.
This family-friendly event is a chance for young people living with diabetes and their whānau to connect, enjoy the pool together, and contribute to our nationwide One Million Minutes of Movement challenge. (Note: this is a public pool session — we’ll be enjoying the space alongside others.)
Come along earlier to support the Blenheim Lions Club “Lap the Map” walk for diabetes awareness — a great way to add even more minutes. Meet at 9am at Raupo Cafe and enjoy a leisurely walk along the Taylor River Reserve.
Registrations (for the swim) are essential and close Thursday, 13 November.
To register or find out more, please contact amanda@diabetes.org.nz.
Bring along:
Togs and towel
Water bottle
Diabetes supplies
Afternoon snack
Please note:
Children 5yrs old and under require an adult swimming with them and to remain within arms reach at all times
Children 9yrs old and under must be actively supervised at all times (watching and able to provide immediate assistance if required)
This is all about spending time together, staying active, and being part of something bigger this Diabetes Action Month.
label: Community & Culture

description:
ENM/Poly Speed Dating, Are you looking to meet like-minded people who embrace polyamory? Join us for an exciting evening of Poly Speed Dating! This event is for those who practice or are interested in consensual non-monogamy, offering a safe and inclusive environment to connect and potentially spark new friendships/relationships.

Price includes a drink and delicious food at the break!

We will have a private function space for this event.

When you arrive you will get a name label and your complimentary first drink, and will have time to settle in and mingle a little.

You will be Speed Dating with around 10 people over the course of the evening. You will have 7 minutes to chat to each person.
You then decide if you want to meet your Speed Dates again and tick interested on your form if you do. Only if the feeling is mutual will we email you each other’s contact details.

There will be an intermission where platters of food will be served, and you can buy yourself another drink if you like.

description:
Ziggy Alberts tickets, Presented by: Commonfolk
ARIA-accredited and APRA Award-winning artist Ziggy Alberts will return to New Zealand this November as part of his New Love World Tour, following three years of extensive touring across Europe, the UK, North and South America, Asia, and regional Australia. Celebrating the release of his seventh studio album, New Love, Ziggy will return to New Zealand for the first time since 2023, with three special shows in Christchurch, Wellington, and Auckland.
From his early days busking the streets of Byron Bay to selling out venues like London’s Royal Albert Hall, Ziggy’s journey has been defined by grassroots touring, heartfelt songwriting, and an unwavering independent spirit.
The New Zealand leg of the tour kicks off on Thursday 13 November at Christchurch Town Hall, followed by Meow Nui in Wellington on Friday 14 November, and concludes at Auckland’s Powerstation on Saturday 15 November. This tour will showcase Ziggy’s signature solo style - spirited, raw, and deeply authentic - the kind of direct connection that has earned him over one billion streams, multiple awards, and a loyal global fanbase.
Fans can look forward to favourites like ‘Days in the Sun’ and ‘Runaway’, which recently surpassed 100 million streams, alongside new tracks from New Love - an album crafted for live performance. Featuring hit singles 'New Love’, 'Where Does the Love Go?' and latest single, ‘I’m With You’ the record marks a return to simplicity and authenticity, blending folk, rock, and country influences to create a cohesive yet dynamic listening experience.
Alberts’ year of New Love is not one to miss. This leg of the world tour will celebrate connection, authenticity, and music’s ability to bring people together. Don’t miss the chance to see Ziggy Alberts live on the New Love World Tour 2025
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Week: Tragedies Tour, Come and hear stories of those who met sad, shocking and untimely ends. This tour traverses some of the older parts of the story where historic headstones mark the stories of lives lost too soon: accidents, murder, misadventure and those who fell by their own hand.
This tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions so is not suitable for everyone.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day 1 hour before the tour starts by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
This tour is approximately 2 hours long.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
If you have purchased tickets for other people can you please pass our tour information on to them as well.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Gong Bath at Vogelmorn Hall, $20 -tickets via link: https://events.humanitix.com/gong-bath-at.../tickets
*Limited door sales for $25*
*Please bring a yoga mat, pillow, eye mask and blanket - or whatever it is you need to feel most warm and comfortable *
Discover the transformative effects of sound therapy with this 1-hour gong bath experience.

During this session, participants will be surrounded by the resonant vibrations of gongs, carefully designed to induce deep states of relaxation and calm. As you settle into the experience, allow the soothing tones to wash over you, releasing tension and promoting a sense of inner peace.

Scientific studies have highlighted the benefits of sound therapy, particularly gong baths, in reducing stress and promoting overall well-being. The rhythmic patterns and overtones of the gongs can help entrain brainwaves, leading to a meditative state and improved mental clarity.

Beyond the immediate effects, many participants report experiencing lasting benefits such as improved sleep, reduced anxiety, and enhanced mood following a gong bath session. By immersing yourself in the healing vibrations of the gongs, you can tap into a deeper sense of relaxation and rejuvenation.

Whether you're looking to unwind after a long day or explore new avenues of self-care, this 1-hour gong bath offers a unique opportunity to reconnect with yourself and find balance amidst the hustle and bustle of daily life. There will be cups of tea available afterwards to help us integrate and ground.

**THIS EVENT IS RESTRICTED TO 40 PEOPLE ONLY**

Disclaimer
Gong baths are safe and supportive for most people. However, please consult your doctor or mental health professional before attending if you:
-have a pacemaker or other implanted medical device
-live with epilepsy or a sound-sensitive condition
-are in the first trimester of pregnancy
-are experiencing severe or unmanaged mental health challenges (such as psychosis, schizophrenia, or PTSD)
If you have recent injuries, surgeries, or other health concerns, let me know so we can make sure you’re comfortable.
Everyone responds differently to sound. If at any point during the session you feel overwhelmed or uncomfortable, you are welcome to sit up, move gently, or step outside. Your wellbeing always comes first.
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Halloween Nightlife Crawl Wellington 2025, Halloween Nightlife Crawl Wellington 2025
Unleash your inner ghoul! Join the Halloween Nightlife Crawl in Wellington on Oct. 31, 2025. 4+ venues, specials & costumes!

About this Event


Halloween Nightlife Crawl – Wellington 2025 🎭

On Friday, October 31st, 2025, the Halloween Nightlife Crawl brings you through a curated mix of Wellington’s top bars, lounges, and clubs. One ticket gives you access to 4+ venues, exclusive Halloween drink specials, and a night full of music and costumes across the city.




What’s Included
Entry to multiple nightlife venues
Crawl wristband for access and specials
Digital crawl map for easy navigation
No cover charges
DJs and entertainment at every stop


Event Schedule
🔑 Check-In | 7:30–10:30 PM – Pick up your wristband at the first stop.
🍹 Crawl Time | 8:30–11:30 PM – Move between bars and lounges at your own pace.
🎉 Final Party | 11:30 PM–2 AM – Everyone meets at the closing venue for the big finish.



Quick Details
🎟 Tickets start at $15 (Early Bird). Prices rise as the event approaches.
👻 Costumes encouraged — from glam to scary, the night is yours.
📍 Venues announced soon. Full lineup will be available on the Digital Crawl Map.
🔞 18+ only. Government-issued ID required.



18+ Event / Valid ID Required


Helpful Tips
Arrive on Time: Wristbands must be collected at the designated check-in venue by 10:30 PM. Late arrivals cannot be accommodated — no wristband, no entry.
Send a Friend: If you can’t make check-in, you may authorize a friend to pick up your wristband so you don’t miss out.
Know the Schedule: Each venue’s times are listed in the Digital Crawl Map. Drink specials and crawl access are only valid during the hours posted.
Stay Informed: Always review the Digital Crawl Map link on the morning of the event for the latest updates and any last-minute changes.
_______________________________________


Important Terms & Disclaimers
Age Requirement
All participants must be 18+ with a valid government-issued photo ID. Entry will not be granted without ID.
Wristbands
A wristband is required for entry at all participating venues. You must present your ticket or QR code at check-in to receive it. Wristbands must remain visible throughout the night. If you fail to pick up your wristband during the scheduled window, no replacement will be provided.
Tickets & Refund Policy
All ticket sales are final — no refunds, exchanges, or transfers. If the event is canceled in full, your ticket (minus fees) will be automatically refunded. Venues, times, and drink specials may be modified without notice.
Venue Rules
Each venue reserves the right to deny entry or remove guests for intoxication, capacity limits, inappropriate dress, or disruptive conduct. No refunds will be issued if entry is refused for these reasons.
Capacity & Timing
Some stops may reach capacity during the event. Admission is first-come, first-served, and your ticket does not guarantee immediate access to any specific location. Late arrivals may face delays in entry.
Self-Guided Experience
This is a self-led crawl — no host will escort groups between venues. Use the Digital Crawl Map to navigate. If staff at a venue are not aware of the crawl, contact the rep listed on the map and proceed to another participating venue if needed.
Drink Specials
Promotions are determined by each venue and may change or end without advance notice.
Security & Dress Code
All venues conduct their own security screening. Wristbands do not bypass these checks. Costumes must not include weapons (real or replica) or offensive themes. Violations may result in denied entry without refund.
Behavior Expectations
Respect venue staff, security, and fellow attendees. Aggressive or damaging behavior may result in removal without a refund.
Liability Notice
By purchasing a ticket and attending, you voluntarily accept all risks related to participation, including alcohol consumption, injury, illness, property loss, or incidents caused by other attendees. You waive any claims against the organizers, affiliates, staff, and participating venues. You also agree to indemnify and hold harmless these parties from any expenses or claims resulting from your actions.
Event Continuity
This event will run rain or shine. Venues and schedules may change. Check the Digital Crawl Map and your email on event day for the latest information.
Acknowledgment
By purchasing a ticket, you confirm that you have read, understood, and agreed to these terms and accept full responsibility for your participation.

description:
From Pemberley to Pipitea: Celebrating Jane Austen's 250th Birthday, From Pemberley to Pipitea: Celebrating Jane Austen's 250th Birthday
Marking 250 years since Austen’s birth this romp through her irreverent Juvenilia is spliced with deliciously pompous gems from Aotearoa’s earliest newspapers.

From the drawing rooms of Georgian England to the dusty streets of Victorian Wellington – the pretensions of polite society never change.

To mark 250 years since the birth of Jane Austen, her wildly funny Juvenilia is brought to life, including The Beautifull Cassandra, The History of England, Love and Friendship – and more.

Between Austen’s sharpest barbs you’ll hear genuine gems from New Zealand’s early newspapers, courtesy of Papers Past: gossip, pomposity, early etiquette advice, and scandalous society mishaps.

The result? A sparkling, one hour romp proving that the absurdities of status, marriage and manners travel across oceans, continents and centuries.

Performed as a series of readings with lightning character swaps, sly narration, and just a hint of scandal, this is Austen as you’ve never heard her: young, bold, and perfectly at home in 19th century Wellington!


Booking is REQUIRED.
Cost: $25
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/from-pemberley-to-pipitea-celebrating-jane-austens-250th-birthday/

description:
Futuna Lecture Series 2025: Francis Kéré, The Futuna Lecture Series commenced in 2011 and has been one of the main annual events on the NZ Architectural calendar for the last 14 years. It is the Futuna Chapel Trust’s major fundraiser each year and attracts a large audience of architects, architectural designers, technicians, architecture and design students and interested members of the public. The Trust exists solely on koha/donations as well as financial support from selected sponsors and donors.
Our sponsors, Dulux NZ, APL, Plytech, Warren Trust and the Auckland, Christchurch and Wellington NZIA branches have continued their support for the Futuna Lecture Series 2025.
This year the Trust welcomes three new sponsors being Roofing Industries Limited, AGP and Big River Panels. The additional support of these new sponsors is very much appreciated and ensures that the Futuna Chapel Trust can continue to attract speakers to NZ of a similar calibre to that of the 2025 Futuna Lecture, Francis Kéré.
The Trust takes this opportunity to thank Metalcraft Roofing for their support of the Futuna Lecture Series from 2012 - 2024.
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work and well as that of the Kéré Foundation.
The Trust will donate 20% of the ticket income to the Kéré Foundation to support the work of Francis Kéré in Gando, Burkina Faso.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all funds raised from the Futuna Lecture Series go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust. Please register using the ticket types of $10, $15, $25 or $30 GST inclusive. Booking fees are in addition to the ticket prices.
BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
There will be 15 Design CPD points available for NZ registered architects attending the event. Please include your NZRAB registration number when purchasing Architect tickets
label: Community & Culture

description:
Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever, Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever
STARTS: 1pm, SUNDAY 5 OCT

In 2004, Georgina Beyer, the first openly transgender Member of Parliament in the world, famously confronted members of Destiny Church during the Enough Is Enough rally on the grounds of Parliament.

Never a bystander, Georgina faced down the bigots, telling them straight, “Your hatred is totally intolerable!” This was just one of many significant moments that shaped the life of the extraordinary Georgina Beyer.

Born in Wellington, Georgina went on to have an unprecedented local, national and international impact through her commitment to equality and her desire to give everyone the opportunity to reach their full potential in society.

Join us for this special 90-minute walking tour as we pay tribute to the late Georgina (1957–2023) by visiting locations around central Wellington that shaped her journey. Along the way, we’ll honour some of her heroes and listen to first-hand archival audio clips that showcase her humour and resilience.

Georgina’s story is defiantly optimistic – confronting hardship and using her lived experience to change the world for the better.

Time/Date: 1pm, Sunday 5 October 2025

Starts: meet outside St Peters Church, 211 Willis Street

Ends: Vivian Street

Duration: 90 minutes

Cost / Bookings: the tour is free but you do need to register here: https://walktoursnz.wordpress.com/book/

Accessibility information: the tour is on flat public footpaths. Tours are limited to approximately 20 walkers.

Image courtesy of the amazing Kym Strathdee
label: Community & Culture

description:
Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever (Wellington Heritage Festival), Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever (Wellington Heritage Festival)
STARTS: 1pm, SUNDAY 2 NOV

In 2004, Georgina Beyer, the first openly transgender Member of Parliament in the world, famously confronted members of Destiny Church during the Enough Is Enough rally on the grounds of Parliament.

Never a bystander, Georgina faced down the bigots, telling them straight, “Your hatred is totally intolerable!” This was just one of many significant moments that shaped the life of the extraordinary Georgina Beyer.

Born in Wellington, Georgina went on to have an unprecedented local, national and international impact through her commitment to equality and her desire to give everyone the opportunity to reach their full potential in society.

Join us for this special 90-minute walking tour as we pay tribute to the late Georgina (1957–2023) by visiting locations around central Wellington that shaped her journey. Along the way, we’ll honour some of her heroes and listen to first-hand archival audio clips that showcase her humour and resilience.

Georgina’s story is defiantly optimistic – confronting hardship and using her lived experience to change the world for the better.

Time/Date: 1pm, Sunday 2 November 2025

Starts: meet outside St Peters Church, 211 Willis Street

Ends: Vivian Street

Duration: 90 minutes

Cost / Bookings: the tour is free but you do need to register here: https://walktoursnz.wordpress.com/book/

Accessibility information: the tour is on flat public footpaths. Tours are limited to approximately 20 walkers.

Image courtesy of the amazing Kym Strathdee

This tour is part of the amazing Wellington Heritage Festival - https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz

description:
Radio Hauraki 'The Big Show' • Beervana Warm Up Show, We’re going BIG to warm up for the BIGGEST beer weekend in the capital.
Next Thursday, @radiohaurakinz are bringing The Big Show to Lyall Bay - broadcasting their @beervananz Warm-Up Show live from Parrotdog Bar.
Roll in early to score one of 100 FREE Backbone Tees and hang with The Big Show crew. Then pull up a stump for a cold pint of Parrotdog, perfectly paired with dinner from two Wellington food icons – @oikoshellenic and @tommytomato.
@oikoshellenic will be serving charcoal-grilled chicken, slow-cooked lamb, and charred eggplant, all tucked into their house-made pita.
@tommytomato will be firing up the @gozney for slices of hot, crispy pizza.
On the sounds we have DJ Karl Gebbie.
On tap we’ll be pouring our brand-new Alcoholic Ginger Beer, alongside all the usual suspects.
See you next week!
#parrotdogbar #haurakinz #thebigshow #beervanawarmup #nice

description:
Ignite Alumni Pub Quiz, Are you a past consultant with Ignite? Do you want to reconnect with other consultants, test your general knowledge, and be in with a chance to win some cool prizes? Then you are invited to our very first IGNITE ALUMNI EVENT - Pub Quiz Style!
Ignite Consultants Wellington is hosting a Pub Quiz for all consultants past and present. This is your opportunity to catch up with other consultants outside of your projects, meet new people, and show off your quiz skills. Your time as a consultant might have come to an end but you are always part of the Ignite whānau as our Alumni!
The quiz will be held at the Cavern Club on the 7th of October, 2025 kicking off at 7pm. You are welcome to make your own teams, or you can choose to be allocated a team. We will do our best to put you with consultants from the same project as much as possible. If you're a Dunedin alum we would love to have you there as well! Teams are 4-6 people.
Tickets for this event ARE LIMITED- so get in quick! A $5 registration fee will go towards the running of the event and supporting Ignite.
We would really love to see you there our amazing Alumni!
label: Community & Culture

description:
From Pemberley to Pipitea: Celebrating Jane Austen's 250th Birthday, From Pemberley to Pipitea: Celebrating Jane Austen's 250th Birthday
Marking 250 years since Austen’s birth this romp through her irreverent Juvenilia is spliced with deliciously pompous gems from Aotearoa’s earliest newspapers.

From the drawing rooms of Georgian England to the dusty streets of Victorian Wellington – the pretensions of polite society never change.

To mark 250 years since the birth of Jane Austen, her wildly funny Juvenilia is brought to life, including The Beautifull Cassandra, The History of England, Love and Friendship – and more.

Between Austen’s sharpest barbs you’ll hear genuine gems from New Zealand’s early newspapers, courtesy of Papers Past: gossip, pomposity, early etiquette advice, and scandalous society mishaps.

The result? A sparkling, one hour romp proving that the absurdities of status, marriage and manners travel across oceans, continents and centuries.

Performed as a series of readings with lightning character swaps, sly narration, and just a hint of scandal, this is Austen as you’ve never heard her: young, bold, and perfectly at home in 19th century Wellington!


Booking is REQUIRED.
Cost: $25
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/from-pemberley-to-pipitea-celebrating-jane-austens-250th-birthday/


Health & Safety
Please contact the event host for health & safety information.

Block Party, Block Party

We’re creating a safe and fun space for the whole community to enjoy. There will be jumping castles, free food, exciting activities for kids, and plenty of fun for all ages.

Bring your friends, whānau, and neighbours along—it’s the perfect way to spend the evening together.

description:
Heritage Festival Open Day, Join us for an open day in the bell tower of Wellington Cathedral of St Paul, where you can uncover its unique history and see the bellringers come out to play.
Take a tour through our ringing chamber and belfry, and see our 140-year-old bells up close. You will have a chance to watch the ringers in action, and maybe even have a go at chiming our 1500kg tenor bell, the largest swinging bell in New Zealand! Discover the secret world of bells and bellringing, something the public doesn't normally get to see. You may have never known that people are pulling on the ropes to make the bells ring! *One of the few towers in the world accessible by lift!
**Entry by donation**
Health & Safety
Please be aware that touching the bell ropes and access to the bells outside of the designated viewing areas is strictly prohibited. You will only be permitted to handle a bell rope under the guidance and supervision of a bellringer. Hearing protection is not required in the ringing chamber, but earmuffs will be provided whilst in the belfry viewing gallery if the bells are going to be rung.
Location
James Thomas Bell Tower, Wellington Cathedral of St Paul, 2 Hill Street, Thorndon 6011
label: Community & Culture

description:
Tangihanga, Created and performed by Kristyl Neho

Tangihanga is a solo drama-comedy centred around Jess - a devoted daughter whose father, Karanipa, has passed away. As Jess’ whānau gathers at the marae to mourn, tensions rise, secrets are revealed, and long-held family dynamics begin to unravel. Neho masterfully embodies over 30 characters, capturing the complexity of grief, cultural identity, and the strength of whānau. This bold, emotionally charged, and often hilarious performance speaks to the heart of Aotearoa.

“A graceful celebration of the power of theatre to create and tell a story.” - Tanya Piejus, Regional News

Audience care: Contains themes of grief and loss. Recommended for audiences aged 9+.
label: Arts & Theatre

As Wellington embraces the creativity of World of Wearable Art®, indulge in a culinary journey unlike any other, perfectly complementing the magic of this year's show. Explore our menus below.
Booking is essential.

Salmon & horseradish roulade
Vegetable madras vol-au-vent
Crab finger sandwich
Brandy-soaked sultana scone & cream
Apricot macaron
Calamansi mille-feuille

Forest berry delice

Served with bottomless T.W.G. Tea

Our Classic High Tea menu can be adapted to vegetarian, vegan and gluten-free diets.

Smoked salmon mousse, beetroot, buckwheat blini
Parmesan custard tart
White chocolate and raspberry profiterole, pâté de fruits
Macaron of the day
Rhubarb meringue tartlet
Pear scone with vanilla cream

Served with bottomless T.W.G. Tea

Our Classic High Tea menu can be adapted to vegetarian, vegan and gluten-free diets.
---

CHILDREN'S HIGH TEA
AVAILABLE FOR UNDER 12 YEAR OLDS | $25 PER PERSON


Ham and cheese slider
Fried chicken
Mini pizza
Oat cookie
Strawberry jam pop pie
Scone of the day

---

Terms and Conditions & Cancellation Policy
Our Aurora High Tea cannot be modified for dietary requirements. However, our Classic High Tea is available in a Vegetarian, Vegan and Gluten Free version. Please note, we are unable to accommodate dietary requirements without prior notice.
If not already stated and confirmed at the time of reservation, guest numbers must be confirmed 48 hours prior to arrival.
A credit card must be provided at the time of reservation to secure the booking.
High Tea reservations cancelled within 24 hours prior to arrival will incur a cancellation fee of 100% of the total booking.
No-shows will be charged a cancellation fee of 100% of the total booking.
Decreases in attendee numbers will not be accepted within 24 hours before arrival, and charges will apply based on the confirmed final count.

description:
World Chase Tag Casual Game Night, World Chase Tag Casual Game Night
Come play Chase Tag at the Kilbirnie Recreation Center.

Come along to our casual game sessions. These will be open to anyone wanting to play and will be social, casual based rather than keeping score. We will play various versions of tag games: such as Ultimate Tag (which involves multiple evaders), Flight Club (which involves king of the hill format), and Chase-Off (the team version, as seen in World Chase Tag competition videos).
World Chase Tag was formed by Christian Devaux in 2012 after a game of Tag with his son in their back garden. A year later, he was joined by his brother, Damien, and together they set about turning the oldest game into the newest sport.


Cost:
-$4.50


Contact us:

-Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/capitalchasetag


Join the facebook community:
- https://www.facebook.com/groups/capitaltag

description:
Kapiti Crop Swap WAIKANAE, Kapiti Crop Swap WAIKANAE
THIS INVITE IS FOR THE WAIKANAE SWAP😁🌱
Everyone is welcome to our CROP SWAP meetings!
1st Saturday of the month – Otaki (1-2pm)
2nd Saturday of the month – Raumati (1-2pm)
3rd Saturday of the month – Pukerua Bay (3-4pm)
4th Saturday of the month – Waikanae (2-3pm)
To be clear, at Crop Swap, we swap more than just crops! We share everything homegrown and homemade: Vegetables, fruits, herbs, plants, seedlings, flowers, seeds, baking, preserves, sauces, jam and all things yummy! You can also bring everything garden and kitchen related like empty containers, tools, labels, planting pots, worm juice, coffee grounds, gardening magazines, cook books, recipes, a SKILL…possibilities are endless.
The key is that this is a cashless event, no koha can offered or accepted.
This is generally how a Crop Swap will run:
2-2.15pm
• People arrive with their crops and put them out on the tables provided.
• You are then free to chat and mingle with your fellow garden enthusiasts, exchange tips, make new friends or just wait until it starts.
2.15-2.45pm
• We conduct a quick briefing outlining the guidelines for swapping.
• If there is not a lot of people, we can listen to anyone who wants to introduce their crop.
• Once everyone has placed their crops we like to do a Karakia to bless the kai. We want to emphasise our values regarding generous giving and mindful taking.
2.45-3pm
• Close out, put away tables and clear the hall.
The meetings will be held regularly on the 2nd Saturday of every month in Raumati and the last Saturday of every month in Waikanae.
Further information:
1. There will be a koha food box for anyone who wants to donate food or seedlings in addition to their swaps. The Crop Swap team will distribute any koha crop and left over crops to local food pantries.
2. If you do not have any crops to swap but need fresh fruit or veges for the next week, you can bring plants, flowers, seedlings, herbs, eggs, preserves, jams, baking, liquid manure, gardening books, magazines, planting containers, sometimes even chooks who need a new home! We want this to be accessible to everyone, especially those who are struggling to put fresh fruit and veges on the table!
label: Community & Culture
