description:
Sew Your Own Circle Scarf Workshop - Sunday 28 September 2025, Sew Your Own Circle Scarf Workshop - Sunday 28 September 2025
Ideal beginner sewer project! Join eco fashion designer Denise Anglesey from Denise H Design on Sunday 28th September and turn your old sweaters into a unique circle scarf fashion accessory.

Bring along two seen better days sweaters of similar thickness, all other sewing requirements will be supplied.

A fantastic way to repurpose and minimise waste!
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Forest & Bird: Every Last Bird – Birds of Te Araroa Trail, Every Last Bird – Birds of Te Araroa Trail

Book your place now to reserve a chair.

Between November 2023 and March 2024, Te Papa natural history curator Dr Colin Miskelly walked the length of Aotearoa New Zealand on Te Araroa Trail – counting every bird seen or heard along the way. His talk will cover some of the logistics of walking the trail, as well as a summary of the birds encountered. This included looking at what difference (if any) predator trapping had on the abundance of native birds. For a taste of what the talk will cover, see Te Araroa Trail | Te Papa’s Blog.

Colin Miskelly on Mt Crawford, Tararua Ranges:

Our Whare Our Fale Information Session!

The session provides you with more detail on what owning an Our Whare Our Fale home means and what the process will be so you can decide whether an Our Whare Our Fale home will work for you and your family.

At the end of the session you will be given the opportunity to sign a Participation Agreement and from this point we will start the journey with you and your family towards home ownership.

If you haven't yet expressed your interest into the Our Whare Our Fale programme, you can do so here: centralpacificcollective.my.site.com/s/eoi

We would love to see you there!

description:
Randell Cottage Annual Open Day, Tour this small colonial Cottage and marvel that it once housed a couple and their ten children. Share afternoon tea and listen to authors reading their works.
Randell Cottage is a rare example of colonial domestic architecture and is a listed historic place. It retains most of its original 19th century configuration, although modified as a comfortable home for writers from NZ and France. It is only open to the public annually as part of the Festival. The event includes a series of readings from current and past residents.
A limited programme will be offered if weather conditions are poor.

Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/.../randell.../

description:
Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Collaboration Navigating Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Perspective, f🌍 Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Collaboration
Hosted by UNANZ Wellington in partnership with the British High Commission, Wellington
Join us for an engaging evening of insight and diplomacy as we explore how the United Kingdom, New Zealand, and the United Nations are working together to drive global climate leadership.
This timely event brings together perspectives on international cooperation, policy innovation, and the urgent challenges of our climate future. John Pearson, Deputy British High Commissioner at the British High Commission, will deliver a keynote speech followed by an open Q&A, offering a unique chance for attendees to ask questions and be part of the conversation.
Whether you're passionate about sustainability, international relations, or meaningful dialogue, this event offers value, inspiration, and connection.
Why attend?
Learn about climate diplomacy in action
Engage with leaders shaping global climate responses
Network with professionals, students, and changemakers
Enjoy light refreshments in a diplomatic setting
🗓️ Date: Tuesday, 26 August 2025
🕔 Time: 5:00 PM – 6:30 PM
📍 Venue: British High Commission, Wellington
🎟️ RSVP Required – Limited Spaces
Networking Reception: From 6:30 pm with canapes and drinks kindly sponsored by the British High Commission.
FOR ANY DIETARY:
Please email us at ishant.ghulyani@unanz.org.nz
Don't miss this opportunity to be part of a global conversation, right here in Wellington.

description:
Kai Sovereignty - Parihaka's Maara Kai and Growing for Communities, Climate and Community Activist Tuhi-ao Bailey will talk about Parihaka’s steps towards kai sovereignty, their award winning māra kai and planning a papakāinga to be resilient in the face of Climate Change.
This will be followed by an action-focused discussion led by chef and grower Mara Masarotti on how to connect urban growers with spaces to grow kai at scale.

Kid Friendly!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Levin | "Waste-Ed" with Kate, Levin | "Waste-Ed" with Kate
Landfills are designed to last 1,000 years! In this chaotic time of consumerism and climate change, we are facing some big challenges that we need to start facing head on! You can do nothing, and nothing will change, or you can be an imperative cog in the machine that works towards a healthier planet. If you want a place to start your waste minimisation journey or even want to reinforce what you already know, then this 2-hour seminar is for you!

Why join us? You will:

LEARN about what happens to our waste once it leaves the curbside.
ACQUIRE tips/tricks and life hacks that will help you deal with/manage your waste better.
BE CHALLENGED to reduce your waste.

Don't miss out on this opportunity full of witty humor, reality checks, and encouragement that may also challenge your thinking around trash! Secure your spot in this 2-hour seminar today by buying a ticket.

description:
Pinhole Photography - Three Day Creative Arts holiday programme, Did you know that any object that can be made light tight can be turned into a camera? Come along to this three-day workshop and choose an object – it could be a tea pot, a book, a coffee jar – to turn into a pinhole camera to then create black and white photographs with.

We’ll work in the darkroom and explore the process of loading your camera with silver gelatin paper, before making exposures in the garden around the historic Inverlochy house, testing different angles and perspectives. We’ll then return to the darkroom to develop your photographic negative, and print it as a positive. You’ll leave the course with a series of atmospheric pinhole photographs, having experienced the magic of hands-on darkroom printing.

Bring a water bottle and morning tea. Recommended age for this course is tweens & teens ages 10 and above.

Monday - Wednesday, 22 - 24 September, 10 am - 1 pm daily.

This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including pottery, jewellery making, animation and sewing head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.

description:
Manawa Karioi Working Bees, Our track maintenance and planting working bees are focussing on plant species diversity rather than large planting quantities. We have ordered 500 special trees from the Berhampore Nursery. We are in this for the long haul and a forest that contains a wide range of plant species will, in turn, attract a wider range of birds, lizards, and invertebrates. A wider range of plant species also allows for the forest to naturally regenerate and helps prevent weed species from establishing.
Tools are provided, bring sturdy shoes and a water bottle, Working bees are held every Sunday in June (except June 1st - Kings Birthday Weekend) and August 2025.
Meeting at the Information Shelter in the Tapu te Ranga Marae car park at the end of Danube Street in Island Bay. Children are welcome with parents or guardians.

description:
Manu Park Site Viewing, Manu Park Site Viewing
Meet us and find out how you can build your dream home in a new subdivision that combines outstanding natural beauty and a real sense of community.
The agent is on-site at the end of Karuhiruhi Street every Sunday between 10.00am - 11.00am.
Since its establishment in 2018, Manu Park has become a highly sought-after community, with Stages One and Two fully sold out. Don’t miss your chance to secure a piece of this paradise in Stage 3, where only 8 sections remain.
Manu Park isn’t just a place to live—it’s a place to belong. Designed with families in mind, it offers a safe and welcoming environment where kids can ride their bikes down quiet streets, explore nature on their doorstep, and grow up knowing their neighbours. Centrally located near Waikanae township it offers expansive open spaces and a strong sense of community; Manu Park is a neighbourhood where friendships flourish and families thrive.
Nestled within protected native bush, Manu Park offers breathtaking surroundings, generously sized sections, and the opportunity to build a home tailored to your vision and lifestyle. Named after the Māori word for bird, it sits beside the renowned Nga Manu Nature Reserve, close to Waikanae’s excellent schools and amenities, just minutes from the beach, and under an hour from Wellington city.
Teaming up with local building companies, Manu Park offers House and Land packages for a seamless home-building experience. Visit Manu Park to explore Design and Build opportunities to create a home that perfectly fits your lifestyle.
Don’t miss this rare opportunity to be part of a vibrant community where nature and modern living come together. Visit manupark.nz to learn more and secure your section today

description:
bbno$ in Wellington, bbno$ in Wellington

🎶 Don't Miss bbno$ Live in Wellington on Sunday, November 9, 2025! 🎶
Are you ready to experience bbno$ like never before? With chart-topping hits like edamame, it boy and Lalala and 1.5M+ devoted fans, bbno$ is taking over Meow Nui this Sunday, November 9, 2025, and trust us, you don't want to miss this.

With multiple shows lined up, this one ensures to be the ultimate musical experience, where the energy of bbno$ will make you dance, sing, and maybe even cry (in a good way).

Expect an unforgettable performance featuring all your favorite songs and some surprises you've never heard before. So, If you're discovering bbno$ for the first time, this show will blow your mind.

Why This Show is Unmissable
With over 10.3M+ fans streaming their music monthly and viral singles in every playlist, bbno$ is at the peak of their career. If you're a long-time fan or just love the buzz, this show will be one for the books.

P.S. – You don't want to be that person who hears about it later! We will not let you miss this in any way!🎉

Artist's Power Move
bbno$ has been setting the stage on fire with performances that leave fans begging for more. With an incredible setlist and live versions of your favorite songs, you'll leave with stories to tell (and maybe a few epic selfies). Follow bbno$ on AllEvents to get hyped for the event!

description:
Northern Suburbs Big Spring Clean!, Hurray, it's nearly spring! Whether you're 8 or 80 come along and show your love for our neighbourhood and come along to this year's Community Spring Clean. This year we're going for Saturday 20th September, which also happens to be UN Community Clean Up Day.
Meet at Pukehuia Park at 10.30am to collect protective gear and rubbish bags, and then head out around our neighbourhood to collect what you can. You might like to head to somewhere you know is particularly rubbish-y around our suburb.
Bring your rubbish back to the park for a weigh-in and to be collected by the Council. Then celebrate your hard work and grab a free sausage or two off the BBQ.
Bring your friends and neighbours and join the fun and satisfaction of making our home a nicer place.
Organised by Newlands Anglican and Newlands Baptist Churches. For more info contact office@newlandsanglican.org.nz or get in touch with Rebecca on 021 0869 9235.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Matiu-Somes Island Trip, Matiu-Somes Island Trip
Join our club trip across to Matiu-Somes Island. Enjoy a pot luck lunch with time to explore the island before conducting an underwater clean up dive by the wharf (conditions permitting).

After a BBQ dinner it is time for a walk before dessert to observe the Little Blue Penguins returning to their nests at sunset and to hunt for Giant Weta and Tuatara.

Sunday morning is a great time to relax, continue exploring the island before the boats arrive and to conduct a beach clean up before catching a ferry home.

This is a great experience for the whole family.

$100pp + Ferry
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Permaculture for People & Place, Permaculture for People & Place
🌱 Permaculture for People & Place - New Workshop at Mangaroa Farms. Led by our resident permaculture enthusiast Halina Horn, experience a hands-on learning journey for the whole whānau. Come get your hands in the soil, explore the garden, and grow over a 4 week course alongside your tamariki 🌻

Together, we’ll learn to care for land, food, and each other. We’ll achieve this through learning about permaculture systems, composting, water wisdom, nature play, and storytelling.

This event is friendly for kids and adults alike - a great opportunity to get family connection over earth-based practices going.

HOW IT WORKS:
🌀 Sign up for 4 x Saturdays in Nov (1st, 8th, 15th, 22nd) at the link below.

🕙 Each event runs from 10am – 1pm | 298 Whitemans Valley road, Upper Hutt

👦 For families, educators, grandparents, & curious growers (ages 5+)

💚 Different adults and kids ticket options available

This is the first of many permaculture education seasonal offerings designed to re-root us in the rhythms of nature.

The second block course in November will cover key themes in seeds, soil, spring growth, plant communities and more... so come along to continue the learning journey.

Spots are limited. Come and grow with us.

🔗 Book now at https://store.mangaroa.org/products/permaculture-for-people-and-place

📧 Questions?

description: October Walk and Weed, Come and help support the local awa, and water quality for the harbour. We are weeding around local planting to ensure they survive, and picking up rubbish in and around the awa. Meet at Dimmock st side of Onepoto park. We have rubbish grabbers and bags, bring gumboots and gloves. Walk and weeds are the last Sunday of every month.

description:
Ruamahanga Farm learning day, At this Toru Trail, we look forward to a day of planting, learning and creativity at Ruamāhanga Farm. Just outside Martinborough, Ruamahanga Farm Foundation are bringing the local community together to help restore wetlands and provide greater access to the awa. The restoration is a foundation for Te Reo o te Wai, an arts and conservation programme for local primary schools.


Our hosts Jane Riddiford and Rod Sugden will share the story of the land and the conversion of a traditional stock and crop farm into a regenerative, community oriented venture. They will involve us in some of the experiential ways they are helping children and young people connect to hidden places along the Ruamāhanga. The day will include planting trees and grasses along a new wetland walk combined with nature based story telling, art and creative writing. We will have a shared lunch by the awa or under canvas if it is wet.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Reimagining Construction: Participatory, Circular, and Open by Design, This presentation examines how the principles of participatory, circular, and open design can transform construction by bringing human and ecological values into the heart of how we build.
Drawing from both ancient timber framing traditions and modern innovations, it demonstrates how modularity and standardisation unlock flexibility, efficiency, and customisation while supporting sustainable, locally-rooted solutions.
A key focus is placed on design for disassembly and reassembly, enabling buildings and their components to be reused and adapted over time—reducing waste, lowering environmental impact, and fostering resilience for current and future communities.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day, Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day
Once a year, we throw open the gates and invite you behind the scenes at Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. It’s your chance to explore the only public botanic garden in Aotearoa dedicated solely to native plants. Discover the people, plants, and projects that make it special.

Meet our team, chat with partner organisations, join an activity, and find out how we’re working together to protect and restore our natural environment. Whether you’ve never been to Ōtari before or it’s been a while, come along, get curious, and reconnect with nature!

On the day:

10 am-2 pm: Tū Mātau Ora – Taonga Tākaro (Traditional Māori games) on the lawn

10 am-2 pm: Conservation community partner stalls

10 am-2 pm: Plant sale – native plants grown right here in the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust Nursery

10:30 am, 11:30 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Behind-the-scenes tours with Ōtari staff (sign up on the day)

10 am -12:30 pm: Rongoā pani (balm) making workshop – learn about traditional Māori plant uses and make a balm to take home. Tickets $10 which goes directly to the Ōtari-Wilton's Bush Trust. Available soon!

10:30 am, 11:45 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Author talks – Ruth Paul, Phil Sirvid, Leon Perrie, and Michael Szabo discuss their recent books

11 am: Lions Ōtari Plant Conservation Laboratory staff show and tell – see our orchid conservation work up close

11 am & 1 pm: String Bean Puppets – two shows: Once in a Full Moon (Kiwi adventures) and Tree Friends (W**d-busting fun)

1 pm-2 pm: Learn to weave putiputi (flowers) out of Harakeke (flax) with the Ōtari Raranga Weavers. This is a drop in session, but it's best to drop by before 1:30 to give you enough time to create your putiputi.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.
label: Conservation & Environment

Drawing from both ancient timber framing traditions and modern innovations, it demonstrates how modularity and standardisation unlock flexibility, efficiency, and customisation while supporting sustainable, locally-rooted solutions.

description:
SEED AND SEEDLING SWAP: Join us for the launch of Seeds to Feeds Island Bay!, We're starting a new group dedicated to building a kai secure Island Bay, and we'd love for you to be a part of it!
When: Saturday, 18th October, 10 am - 2 pm
Where: Seed to Sea, 38 The Parade, Island Bay
What to expect:
Seed and Seedling Share: Bring your extra seeds and seedlings to swap, or just come and pick up some new ones - we have plenty!
Learn & Create: Discover how to create new plants from your seeds and make your own seed packets.
Delicious Treats: Enjoy coffee, fresh herbal tea, and tasty treats.
Garden Open Day: Explore the beautiful garden at Seed to Sea and meet the chooks!
Share Your Ideas: We want to hear your thoughts on how we can create a kai secure Island Bay.
Seed and seedling swaps are an awesome opportunity for gardeners of all skill levels to collaborate and share what they might have an abundance of.
It's a great way to save money on buying new seedlings, an opportunity to learn from others, and can lead to new varietals in your māra.
Bring something to share if you can, but if not, come as you are – we'll have plenty for everyone!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Rogue Late Lounge | Myele Manzanza + Friends, Popping back from London for a quick visit at his old Welli home base, drummer Myele Manzanza will host a jam session at The Rogue & Vagabond. Late night explorations over old standards & new forms.

You’ve got to be there to be in the know, ya know?!

FREE ENTRY - Koha for the band encouraged
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Scaling Sustainably with Brianne West, founder of Ethique and Incrediballs, Part of the Pegasus Startup World Cup and Sustainable Spring Series
 Globally recognised environmentalist and entrepreneur, Brianne West, redefined industry norms with her bold vision and innovation, transforming a kitchen experiment in Christchurch into a global beauty revolution.
Ethique was the world’s first zero-waste beauty brand and named in Time Magazine’s Best inventions of 2020. It expanded rapidly, saving millions of plastic bottles from landfill in over 20 countries.
Brianne has won many awards including being an Obama Foundation Leader (AsiaPac), Exporter of the Year (American Chamber of Commerce), and NZ EY Young Entrepreneur of the Year, and was a finalist in the 2024 Kiwibank New Zealand Innovator of the year award.
In this workshop, Brianne will share her incredible journey on scaling, and later exiting a purpose driven, sustainable business. Learn about her current venture, Incrediballs which is set to disrupt the beverage industry, and gain practical insights on how to enter new markets while remaining true to your values.
In this workshop, Brianne will share her remarkable journey of scaling - and ultimately exiting, a purpose-driven, sustainable business. She’ll introduce her latest venture, Incrediballs, poised to disrupt the beverage industry, while offering practical insights on breaking into new markets without compromising your values.
Brianne West is a judge for the Pegasus Startup World Cup held on 9 October 2025 at Te Raukura ki Kāpiti. Learn more and book a ticket to the Pegasus Startup World Cup here.
Snacks provided, if you would like to order a coffee, please arrive earlier to avoid noise.

Pop along to Te Aro Zero Waste at Sustainability Trust HQ @ 12pm and do your bit to help make Welly waste-free. We will provide everyone with litter pickers, gloves and buckets.

See you there!

We would love:
- clean adults' clothing
- clean children's clothing

Everything you can offer to us goes on to help us provide for the animals in our care

We'll spend roughly an hour on the streets and waterfront with our litter pickers making our community a waste-free zone.

Pop along to Te Aro Zero Waste at Sustainability Trust HQ @ 12pm and do your bit to help make Welly waste-free. We will provide everyone with litter pickers, gloves and buckets.

description:
Te Hononga hikoi: Taupō Swamp, Te Hononga hikoi: Taupō Swamp
Te Hononga hīkoi enable our members to connect with others in the Wellington Catchments Collective. It's pretty inspiring seeing the activities happening in other catchment groups.

The next Te Hononga hikoi will be at Taupo Swamp in Porirua on the morning of Sunday 21 September at 10am – 11.30pm approx.

Come for a spring stroll and bring friends and family. Bring water and own snacks or fuel up at nearby cafes in Plimmerton.

We will meet in Ulric Street by the pedestrian bridge entrance to the dog park (plenty of parking)

Friends of Taupo Swamp & Catchment Inc was formed in 2018 by a group of Porirua residents. Restoration activities have been focused on the part of the wetlands that is owned by Porirua City Council.

Back in 2018 there was a lot of blackberry on the site. Now, some of the 2019-20 locally sourced plantings by volunteers are 5 metres high. By the end of the current planting season FOTSC will have put in 18K plants. An adjacent planting programme around the Plimmerton Domain coordinated by the local Rotary Club and the Porirua City Council has resulted in 22k trees and plants.

Please register your interest/intention to attend by flicking a short email to . In the event of bad weather we will advise cancellation by 8am and rescheduling for a week later.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
The Great Southern BioBlitz 2025, A bioblitz is all about searching for and recording all the species you can over a set time period.
Zealandia is one of the most biodiversity rich places in the motu(show English translation) and the perfect place to come searching for species over the long weekend. You may well find species that we have seldom seen, so this is fun for you and potentially invaluable information for our conservation team. It’s a great reason to go exploring some of the tracks you might not know well, or at all!
All you have to do is upload your observations of species to iNaturalist. It doesn’t have to be done during those four days. In fact, you’ll have a further 14 days to upload and identify all your observations made during the official period.
The Great Southern BioBlitz 2025 is run by a network of keen citizen scientists from across the globe.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
The Power of Community - Dr Amanda Cahill, "What does it take for communities to lead the renewable energy transition - not just be consulted?"
If one person is positioned well to respond to that question, it is Dr Amanda Cahill.
Goodlife Collective, Sustainability Trust and WEAll Aotearoa are proud to be co-hosting Dr Amanda Cahill, founder of The Next Economy
Don't miss this opportunity to hear Amanda's insights from her work in Australia, which demonstrate how acting on climate change can help catalyse fairer, more regenerative wellbeing economies.
Amanda has worked at the intersection of government, local councils, big companies and communities for 30 years, to support communities to transition to a thriving future.
Amanda is the Founder of The Next Economy, where she supports regional communities across Australia to manage the impacts of decarbonisation and climate change in a way that builds more equitable and regenerative economies. Most of this work has been in coal and industrial regions, where she has brought together government, industry, workers and community groups to co-design transition strategies despite deep-seated tensions. Her work draws on 30 years’ experience working with changemakers across the world to address economic and health inequalities, environmental degradation, women’s rights and climate justice.
Event Programme:
5:15pm - doors open, drinks & nibbles
5:45pm - Welcome & Introduction
6:00-6:30pm - Talk from Dr Amanda Cahill
6:40 - Dialogues & Q&A
7:00(ish!): Networking

About Sustainability Trust: Sustainability Trust are your local experts in sustainability, healthy homes, ethical electricity and supporting our local communities.
About WEAll Aotearoa: WEAll Aotearoa is a non-partisan and independent ‘think and do’ tank working to redesign Aotearoa New Zealand’s economy around the wellbeing of our people and te taiao. WEAll use an evidence-informed approach and focus upstream to develop practical, long-term solutions for the public good.

About Goodlife Collective: Goodlife Collective designs and delivers events and experiences to build connection between people, nature and valuable ideas, in service of unlocking our collective potential.
About Dr Amanda Cahill
Amanda is the Founder of The Next Economy, where she supports regional communities across Australia to manage the impacts of decarbonisation and climate change in a way that builds more equitable and regenerative economies. Most of this work has been in coal and industrial regions, where she has brought together government, industry, workers and community groups to co-design transition strategies despite deep-seated tensions. Her work draws on 30 years’ experience working with changemakers across the world to address economic and health inequalities, environmental degradation, women’s rights and climate justice.
Amanda is a Churchill Fellow and has a PhD from ANU in human geography. She is also a Research Fellow at the University of Melbourne, an Industry Fellow at the University of Sydney and a co-editor of the recently published book: Regional Energy Transitions in Australia: From impossible to possible.
About The Next Economy
Next Economy works with government, industry, investment and community to create the conditions for a rapid, responsible and fair transition to a climate-safe, regenerative and socially just Australian economy.

description:
Volunteer Info Evening- 2/57 Willis Street, Are you ready to make waves in conservation?
Join Mountains to Sea Wellington on our journey to restore and protect our marine and freshwater environments.
This information evening will give anyone interested in volunteering with us an opportunity to hear all about our volunteer programme and meet the MTSW crew.
There are lots of ways you can help us at MTSW! Are you into photography? Do you make a mean cuppa? Love to snorkel? Love to talk about marine critters? Nau mai, haere mai! We’d love your help! In return, we promise you a summer of adventure and fun times.
You're welcome to join us anytime from 5pm, there will be a short presentation at 5.15pm, followed by drinks and kai. There will be Mountains to Sea Wellington Staff onsite, as well as some of our current volunteers who'll be able to give you the inside word on what it's like to volunteer with us!
We’ll be in the Silver Lining Room at 2/57 Willis Street. Entrance is via the lifts in the alleyway to the left of Unity Books, take the lift to level 2.
RSVP HERE: https://forms.gle/URvGHkFxRmEmALgq8 so we know how much pizza to order!

This is a unique opportunity to connect with the incredible music and dance from te pito o te henua, the belly button of the Earth.

The Latin Collective is hosting this koha event as we continue to stregthen the bonds between Aotearoa and Latin America.

Nau mai haere mai. Everyone is welcome!

description:
Weeding Bee 18th October, Weeding Bee 18th October
Kia Ora Koutou

Now we have finished planting we are turning our attention to the all important W**d releasing.
This is essential to keeping the seedlings we have planted this winter from being overwhelmed by grass and weeds.
Also mulching to help with moisture retention over those hot summer days (hopefully we get a summer!)
Meeting at the Nursery on Hana Udy street at 9am
Gloves, tools and sunscreen provided along with a morning tea and an update on the Reserve afterward.
Hope to see you there !



Health & Safety Notice: When working in the Reserve, please ensure your clothing and footwear are appropriate for expected weather conditions (cold, wet or hot) and the terrain (such as holes, hidden objects, blackberry, overhead branches). Trip hazards and slippery tracks are a possibility. Stay clear of waterways. Be cautious if you have allergies and carry the necessary medication. Enjoy your time in the Reserve and please avoid blocking pathways used by other users. Report any accidents, injuries or possible hazards to the H&S Coordinator (021 071 536)

description:
Wellington Timebank Spring Clothes Swap!, All welcome!
Wellington Timebank will be hosting a fun social event for Spring - a clothes swap! Come along to meet and hang out with other Timebank members, and take this opportunity to sustainably refresh and/or clear out your wardrobe for Spring!
Sunday 19 October
10am-1.30pm
Te Aro Zero Waste Centre
2 Forresters Lane, Te Aro
--
How it works:
10am-11am:
Drop off your clothes/accessories etc to swap (washed and in good condition please!).
We welcome clothes and accessories from/for everyone - including kids clothes and pet clothes (?)!
~ Have a hot drink while our team sort out the clothes
~
11.30am-1.30pm:
Swap is open! Go and get yourself a whole new wardrobe!
--
Timebankers receive 1 time credit for bringing clothes, or spend 1 time credit to pick up some new (to you) clothes (if you do both, it's free!).
Non-timebankers can attend for koha, so please feel free to bring your friends and whānau. And encourage them to join the Timebank
All clothing remaining after the swap will be donated to charity op-shops - Aunty Dana's and Opportunity for Animals.
If you would like to do some baking or volunteer (we need some clothes sorters!) for this event, your support would be very much appreciated! Please send me a message/email me on info@wellingtontimebank.org.nz.

description:
The World of Nelsito, Movie Spotlight
The World of Nelsito / El Mundo de Nelsito
Country: Cuba
Genre: Drama
Audio: Spanish
Subtitles: English
Synopsis: Dramatic comedy that introduces us to Nelsito, a 16-year-old autistic boy. After running away from home, he is the victim of a car accident. From his stretcher and through his imaginary pen, Nelsito reveals the dark and hidden side of all those he lives with and those around him: perverse children, murderous women, adorable swindling girls… Now recovered, Nelsito returns home. There we will meet those same characters, now simple neighbours, real, everyday people, but which are the real ones, those common mortals or the ones he has imagined?
Rated: M - Suitable for mature audineces 16 years and over.
Note: Violence, sexual violence & offensive language.
Free Entry | RSVP required |
label: Film & Media

description:
The Festive Flyer, The Festive Flyer
Join us and celebrate Christmas with a delicious lunch and a day out on the train! Saturday 6th December 2025

Get into the festive spirit with Steam Incorporated—perfect for celebrating with colleagues, friends, and family!

Jump onboard our heritage train departing Wellington Station, and nestle down into your seats for a relaxing journey up the coast behind one of our heritage Da class locomotives.

After arriving at the private entry at Tatum, you'll take a short walk across the car park and follow the music into the Pavilion, where we settle in just in time for lunch!

Immerse yourself in a well-crafted meal, created by the talented chefs there. The menu is set to be a classic kiwi style Christmas buffet feast with all the trimmings!

There will be plenty to keep you entertained such as outdoor games, live music, and 2 dinner sittings, so there is plenty of time to tour Tatum, check out Tatum House, and relax in the gardens on the Tatum House Lawn with a drink. You will be advised of your sitting time prior to arrival.

Departing Tatum, climb on board, head to the Lounge Car, grab a drink from the bar and enjoy the journey home. This unforgettable ride hugs the dramatic coastline along the famed Kapiti escarpment, offering sweeping views of the Tasman Sea and rugged cliffs. It’s a rare chance to relive the golden age of rail in one of New Zealand’s most scenic rail corridors as the sun begins to set.

This excursion will be hauled by our 1955-built diesel electric locomotive, Da 1410, and consist of our steel carriages.

Fares (include your return train travel, meal and entertainment)
Adult 13+ yrs - $229
Child 2-12yrs - $189
Infant 0-2yrs - FREE

Thinking of a larger event, or your corporate Christmas Function?
We're pleased to be able to offer some fantastic packages for large groups, or corporate functions with our friends at Tatum. This all inclusive train ride and Christmas lunch combo is a great way to celebrate 2025 with your team! Please contact us via email or call us on 0800 783 264 for a personalized group package.

Please be at your boarding station minimum 10 minutes prior ready to roll, with your tickets, carriage letter and seating allocations at the ready.

Limited Mobility Disclaimer
Tatum does NOT have a platform. This means you must be able to board and disembark the train from ground level with little to no assistance.

Due to the age, design and nature of our heritage carriages, these are not suitable for passengers with limited mobility. If you have any concerns, please contact us on 0800 783 264 to discuss options with our bookings team!

All tickets and seating allocations are sent via email, within 48 hours prior to the departure of this excursion.

Prior booking is essential, make sure you reserve your spot now to avoid missing out on this experience.

description:
Wellington Jazz Festival 2025 | SAMARA JOY, Five-time GRAMMY Award-winning vocalist Samara Joy makes her Aotearoa debut at the Wellington Jazz Festival.
At just 25 years old, Joy has become a breakout jazz sensation, redefining 21st century jazz with her rich tone, refined phrasing, and love and understanding of the Great American Songbook.
Since winning the GRAMMY for Best New Artist in 2023 and earning a spot on Forbes 30 Under 30 list, she has sold out major venues and headlined festivals across the globe - from Carnegie Hall to Jazz at the Lincoln Centre.
Joined by her outstanding seven-piece band at the St James Theatre, Joy will perform music from her critically acclaimed new album Portrait - praised as a “true artistic statement” (The Times) - alongside selections from her back catalogue.
Seamlessly blending the elegance of jazz’s golden age with a modern touch, be sure to secure your seats to see the unforgettable Samara Joy.

THE GARDEN HOTEL - WELLINGTON
We’re turning 2 years old, and we want to celebrate with all of you! We’ve been bringing you beach parties and raves for 2 years and we’re not slowing down. It’s also DJ By Accident’s birthday, so we’re throwing a massive jungle rave filled with our multicoloured line-up from house to techno at The Garden Hotel.
LINE-UP:
• NOT MY SISTER - House
• DJ BY ACCIDENT - Afro-Latin House
• GASPAR - Bounce Singalong Techno
• MALWARE - Hard Techno
Dress code: Party Animals (think jungle creatures, leopard, snakeskin, zebra, cheetah. Get wild!)
See you in the jungle!


***Please Respect the Venue***
*** Important Information ***
• At Jungle Juice we will not tolerate any form of discrimination.
• Look out for each other and please report any antisocial behaviour.
• Remember we all come from different walks of life and we don’t know what others have/are going through. Never judge anyone by who they are.
• We share our time with you in a loving and respectful way and we want everyone to feel this every minute they are at a Jungle Juice event.
• Consent is key – always.
• Have fun and please find us on the decks if you have any issues.

description:
Kapiti Crop Swap WAIKANAE, Kapiti Crop Swap WAIKANAE
THIS INVITE IS FOR THE WAIKANAE SWAP😁🌱
Everyone is welcome to our CROP SWAP meetings!
1st Saturday of the month – Otaki (1-2pm)
2nd Saturday of the month – Raumati (1-2pm)
3rd Saturday of the month – Pukerua Bay (3-4pm)
4th Saturday of the month – Waikanae (2-3pm)
To be clear, at Crop Swap, we swap more than just crops! We share everything homegrown and homemade: Vegetables, fruits, herbs, plants, seedlings, flowers, seeds, baking, preserves, sauces, jam and all things yummy! You can also bring everything garden and kitchen related like empty containers, tools, labels, planting pots, worm juice, coffee grounds, gardening magazines, cook books, recipes, a SKILL…possibilities are endless.
The key is that this is a cashless event, no koha can offered or accepted.
This is generally how a Crop Swap will run:
2-2.15pm
• People arrive with their crops and put them out on the tables provided.
• You are then free to chat and mingle with your fellow garden enthusiasts, exchange tips, make new friends or just wait until it starts.
2.15-2.45pm
• We conduct a quick briefing outlining the guidelines for swapping.
• If there is not a lot of people, we can listen to anyone who wants to introduce their crop.
• Once everyone has placed their crops we like to do a Karakia to bless the kai. We want to emphasise our values regarding generous giving and mindful taking.
2.45-3pm
• Close out, put away tables and clear the hall.
The meetings will be held regularly on the 2nd Saturday of every month in Raumati and the last Saturday of every month in Waikanae.
Further information:
1. There will be a koha food box for anyone who wants to donate food or seedlings in addition to their swaps. The Crop Swap team will distribute any koha crop and left over crops to local food pantries.
2. If you do not have any crops to swap but need fresh fruit or veges for the next week, you can bring plants, flowers, seedlings, herbs, eggs, preserves, jams, baking, liquid manure, gardening books, magazines, planting containers, sometimes even chooks who need a new home! We want this to be accessible to everyone, especially those who are struggling to put fresh fruit and veges on the table!

description:
‘Where there’s smoke’ Legacy Tour - UPPER HUTT SHOW, ‘Where there’s smoke’ Legacy Tour - UPPER HUTT SHOW
‘Where there’s smoke’ is a powerful new theatre production grounded in 10 years of creative wānanga with rangatahi across Aotearoa. The script is backed by evidence and forms parts of Charlizza Matehe’s doctoral research on rangatahi suicide and mental health. It pays tribute to our very first suicide prevention show, Smoke & Mirrors, which toured Aotearoa in 2015 and ignited a kaupapa that has stood the test of time, while suitable for whānau audience, parental guidance is advised due to sensitive themes around suicide and grief. This show was created to open honest, hopeful conversations around mental health and to remind our young people they are not alone. We warmly encourage people working with youth, youth groups and community rōpū to attend together. Email for more information and group bookings

description:
Soundscape Series: Danica Bryant, Danica Bryant is a force to be reckoned with. A pop-folk singer-songwriter with a gritty rock-edge, her music tackles provocative themes from celebrity culture to neurodiversity through an unabashedly queer feminist lens.

Her “playful indie pop” (Rolling Stone) has seen her open for legends like Elton John and Robbie Williams, hit #2 on the NZ Hot Singles Chart with her 2024 release ‘Acid’, and undergo mentorship with Kiwi icon Bic Runga. Bryant has undergone multiple successful New Zealand tours and played festivals including Gardens Magic, Outfield and Cuba Dupa.

With her debut album 'Feast' out this August, Bryant is “venomous yet passionate” (Ambient Light), “cynical but emotional” (NZ Musician), and an unapologetically fresh voice on the pop music scene.

About the Mostly Music Soundscape Series

A curated series of intimate live music experiences showcasing the depth, texture and emotion of sound. Each performance invites you to immerse yourself in a new soundscape, informed by genre, sonic craft, and music as an art form. Designed for music lovers who want more than a background soundtrack, this series celebrates live performance with a diverse range of acclaimed performers.

Saturday 21 June — Nick Granville Trio

Saturday 26 July — Seth Boy Trio

Saturday 30 August — Michelle Velvin Harpist

Saturday 20 September — The Weather Machine

Saturday 27 September — Rameka Tamaki

Saturday 25 October — Danica Bryant

Doors 7:30pm, with events starting at 8pm. Each event will be 60—90 minutes in two sets.

These events will take place inside at The Bond Store, Paraparaumu and are seated with general admission.

The Bond Store is located at 21 Birmingham Street, Paraparaumu. It operates as The Tasting Room which serves food and beverages.

description:
Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland, Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland
Wonderland was Wellington’s first ever amusement park. Based in Miramar, it opened in 1907 and was located near the present-day Wētā Cave. At the time it was one of the biggest amusement parks in the Southern Hemisphere. Its various attractions were originally to be found at the New Zealand International Exhibition of 1906-1907 and were brought to Wellington after that exhibition closed. The park has a fascinating and interesting back story which the panellists will explore.

This very special event will be an unmissable treat for all local history buffs as well as a fabulous journey into Wellington’s and especially Miramar’s past, and features two of Aotearoa’s finest and most acclaimed historical novelists and Wellington City Libraries' own Local History Specialist.

Meet the panel:

Tracy Farr:
Tracy Farr's debut novel The Life and Loves of Lena Gaunt was long­listed for Australia’s Miles Franklin Literary Award, shortlisted for the Barbara Jefferis Award and Western Australian Premier’s Book Awards. Wonderland is her third novel and is set in and during the time of Miramar’s Wonderland.

Philippa Werry:
Multi-award winning historical fiction writer Philippa Werry’s most recent book Iris and me about the travels of Robin Hyde won the Young Adult Fiction Award at the NZ Book Awards for Children and Young Adults. Her numerous other works include award winning fiction, non-fiction, picture books, plays and poetry, with a special emphasis on children and young adults, and a particularly strong focus on Aotearoa / New Zealand stories and history.

And to complete our illustrious panel we have Wellington City Library’s Local History Specialist, Gábor Tóth.

description:
Confessions Booth, ✨ Confessions Booth - Hosted by a Fabulous Drag Host ✨
Wellington, it’s time to spill your secrets… or just sip and enjoy everyone else’s! 👀
Step into the Confessions Booth for a cheeky, interactive night of cocktails, laughs, and anonymous confessions, hosted by a fabulous drag MC. Part comedy, part interactive theatre, part party - guaranteed to keep you laughing, sipping, and maybe confessing…
Here’s how it works:
On arrival, grab a drink and submit a confession on a card or via QR code. Totally optional - sipping cocktails is a perfectly valid choice!
Confessions must be about you only - keep other people’s skeletons in their closet.
You can submit anonymously, or add your name for a little extra spice and interaction with the host (and a chance to win a price).
Selected confessions will be read aloud by our drag MC, who will add cheeky commentary, playful roasts, and audience Q&A.
Not every confession will make it to the stage, but every secret counts and contributes to the fun.
Between confession sets, enjoy music, cocktails, and mingling. After the main show, the party continues with a pop, disco, and house playlist.
Ticket Tiers:
GA - $25: Entry only.
Upgraded - $35: Entry + welcome bubbly 🥂
VIP - $55: Entry + welcome drink (cocktail, wine, beer or Pal) + charcuterie cup + priority seating.
📍 Where: Whisky & Wood, Wellington
📅 When: Thursday 23 October, 7:00pm
Sip. Spill. Repeat. Whether you’re confessing your darkest secrets or just watching the chaos unfold, this is a night of laughs, drinks, and drama you won’t forget.

In this exclusive olfactive experience, indulge in small bites and sip on a glass (or three!) of something delightful, setting the perfect mood for exploring the emotional power of fragrance.

Over the course of the evening, you’ll sample up to twelve unique fragrances, each one tied to a captivating love story that inspired its creation. Whether you're a fragrance enthusiast or a newcomer, this sensory journey is sure to arouse your olfactory senses and deepen your appreciation for the art of perfume.

Curated by ConcernedApe, Symphony of Seasons features a 35-piece orchestra performing the most memorable music from the game, and a screen above the stage playing gameplay footage plus original content created exclusively for this tour.
Concert-goers can look forward to hearing the game’s most cherished songs as they watch their farm grow throughout the seasons and explore some of the valley’s most memorable locations, from Pelican Town to the Skull Cavern, Ginger Island to Calico Desert, the Submarine to the Wizard’s Tower and much more.
Conducted by Sarah-Grace Williams, the shows will be performed by The Metropolitan Orchestra (Sydney, Brisbane, Wellington, Auckland), Christchurch Symphony Orchestra (Christchurch), Australian Pops Orchestra (Melbourne), Perth Symphony Orchestra (Perth) and Southern Cross Symphony (Adelaide).

You’ll be greeted by a singing group of talented Pōneke rangatahi and there’ll be live music throughout the evening. But most importantly, you’ll get to meet the 47 gifted children’s writers, illustrators and translators who are finalists in this year’s awards, and applaud the winners as they are announced.
Tickets (which include food and refreshments at the post-ceremony function) are on sale now via Humanitix for $52.00 plus booking fees. This is a popular event with a limited number of seats, so secure your place today and enjoy this wonderful showcase of the very best books of the year for young New Zealand readers.

description:
Other Futures Big Band - Wellington Jazz Festival, OTHER FUTURES BIG BAND is about multi-disciplinary excellence and celebration of our individual and collective voices in new ways. In this episode, anticipate steaming and reverent swing alongside triumphant soul, dark and scenic textures, and dripped-out golden-age hip-hop cuts. We celebrate artistry with dignity, respect and above all, joy. We swing hard. We groove like humanity depends on it. Groove with us at Meow Nui this Wellington Jazz Festival!
=========
OTHER FUTURES BIG BAND is where musical dreams come alive. It’s about the spark of true individuality, nestled in the art and community of ensemble. The thrill and drama of the showband era re-envisioned for our time. Selections that signify deeper meanings and secret codes. Turntablism sensibility on a symphonic scale. Streamlined, momentous, nimble, angular, adapting, shape-shifting, pulsating with relentless joy and emotion.
OTHER FUTURES BIG BAND is an ongoing project by Daniel Hayles that looks to honour elements of the big band tradition while platforming music and artists unexplored within the style. Expect to hear distinct flavour in new interpretations of original music from Aotearoa and the world.

description:
Flying a tattered flag for New Zealand film: Rudall Hayward’s 60-year career, Flying a tattered flag for New Zealand film: Rudall Hayward’s 60-year career
In this month’s Friends of the Turnbull event, author and lecturer Annabel Cooper will talk about researching New Zealand filmmaker Rudall Hayward, best known for his silent films but also his later feature films ‘Rewi’s Last Stand’ and ‘To Love a Māori’.

Join us at the Library or online. Register if you’d like to join this talk and we'll send you the link to use on the day:

Rediscovering Rudall Hayward
Join us for a fascinating talk by historian and author Annabel Cooper as she delves into the life and legacy of Rudall Hayward — a trailblazer of New Zealand filmmaking.

Although not widely known today, Rudall’s career spanned from the early 1900s to the 1970s. He made four feature-length films during New Zealand’s silent film era, later navigating the financial challenges of accessing new sound equipment to make documentaries, educational films, and two more feature films — Rewi’s Last Stand (1940) and the first New Zealand film to be shot in colour, To Love a Māori (1972).

Drawing on research for her biography of Rudall Hayward and his family, Annabel Cooper will explore his enduring contributions to cinema, his collaborative work with his wives Hilda and Ramai, and the cultural legacy he left behind.

A Friends of the Turnbull Library event
The Friends of the Turnbull Library, Ngā Hoa o te Whare Pukapuka Turnbull, offers a monthly programme of free public talks. These talks are held in the National Library in Wellington and on Zoom. Some of these talks will be repeated in Auckland. The public programme highlights the work of researchers who draw on Turnbull material for their projects and staff who care for and research the collections.

About the speaker
Associate Professor Annabel Cooper taught at the University of Otago for 30 years, and published on a number of New Zealand topics including gender history and film. Her last book, Filming the Colonial Past: The New Zealand Wars on Screen, is the subject of an exhibition, He Riri Awatea: Filming the New Zealand Wars, curated with Ariana Tikao for the New Zealand Portrait Gallery and now showing at Canterbury Museum.
label: Film & Media

description:
Real Black For Me: Zoe Moon presents the music of Roberta Flack, Roberta Flack made an indelible mark on modern popular music.
Over the course of her career, Flack wrote and performed songs that blended jazz, folk, gospel, and R&B into something uniquely her own — music defined by elegance, intimacy, and emotional depth deeply rooted in celebration of black American culture.
From the quiet intensity of The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face to the gently insistent Killing Me Softly with His Song, her recordings
remain timeless, proven again and again by the ways they’ve been reimagined.
In Real Black For Me, artist Zoe Moon and her band — featuring a live string section — revisit and reimagine this extraordinary body of work through a shared sense of the “strange kind of power” of self defined identity.
These arrangements, which Moon has crafted alongside renowned Wellington big band leader, bass player and composer Seth Boy, bring fresh colour and sophistication to Flack’s most celebrated songs alongside lesser-known but equally captivating gems, tracing the arc of an artist whose voice could fill a room or break a heart with a whisper.
An evening for lovers of great songwriting, luminous vocals, and the enduring legacy of one of music’s finest storytellers.
Doors 6.30pm | Show 7pm

description:
Jewellery-making in 8 weeks: Monday nights, Level 2+, This course is for level 2+ and advanced students; it is not open to beginners. This more advanced class is ideal for those who are already competent at soldering simple joins, annealing, and basic tool use on their own.

Students must have completed an 8-week block with ring-making and bezel settings or equivalent. If you have not done one of our 8-week beginner’s classes or are unsure of your level because you may have done a few different shorter classes, please contact us and we can advise you.

A more advanced set of students means that your tutor can support you and the group to take on more exciting and complex challenges. They will work with the group to find appropriate projects for you and for the class as a whole. Each 8-week block may focus on a particular skill topic, rather than doing loads of different topics with each student over the block. This means the students will benefit from a more in-depth learning experience, supported practice, and peer support from fellow students.

Level 2 students learn to solder more competently on their own using chain-making as a way to develop their fine soldering skills. They may create a simple stone setting or ring alongside this challenge project so they have something familiar to hone their skills on, as well as take on a new skill. Their silver project could be a pendant on a handmade chain, a charm bracelet, or a more complex bezel setting.

Level 3 and above students are encouraged to work on their design skills and try new and challenging techniques. They should prepare to have one or two simple projects they can work on self-directed in class—more chains or simple bezel settings are ideal to help them strengthen their soldering skills—alongside a challenge project that might be a shelf setting (an adaptation of a bezel setting that can take faceted stones), a tube setting, or a larger bezel setting for a box or brooch.

This class fee does NOT include materials for any student. All metals and stones, as well as quality findings and chains, are available for purchase each week in the studio. Students are encouraged to keep their silver scrap and find ways to use it thriftily in future projects!

description:
Family event: Explore Omnibirding with Giselle Clarkson, We are thrilled and delighted to announce we are going to be hosting a fabulous school holiday event with the multi-award winning Giselle Clarkson to celebrate the release of her latest book Omnibird: An Avian Investigator’s Handbook, a guide to the art and science of omnibirding.
Giselle Clarkson, the author of The Observologist, will be in Tawa for this very special event to explore the inner workings of the book and delights and wonders of the avian world.
Some birds are so commonplace it’s easy to forget how extraordinary they are. These creatures have a secret eyelid, hollow bones and a two-part brain. They dress in feathers. Omnibird, explores what’s remarkable about the birds all around us and the clues we can all use to become avian investigators.
Giselle is an author, illustrator and cartoonist based in Greytown, known for her work on conservation and environmental topics. She has illustrated award-winning picture books and nonfiction and is a 2023 Arts Foundation Laureate, receiving the prestigious Mallinson Rendel Illustrators Award.
This promises to be an unmissable event for bird and nature lovers of any age.
Books for sale thanks to the Children's Bookshop.
We wish to extend our thanks to Gecko Press for helping make this event happen.
This is a free event.
We expect this event to be very popular so to secure your seat early arrival is suggested.

description:
Jewellery Making - Creative Arts holiday programme for teens, Craft your own rings in this introduction to metal-smithed jewellery making! In this quick paced one session workshop you’ll learn some metalworking fundamentals to turn raw silver, copper and brass into shining wearable rings. Use hammers and stamps to add textures and simple lettering to customise your creation!

Techniques covered:

- Use sizers and jeweller’s callipers to measure ring size
- Use files and sanding to refine and smooth metal edges and surfaces
- Use hammers and stamps to texture and form metal
- Use jeweller’s flame torches to solder join metal
- Use Dremel & bench polishers to refine & finish metal casts into wearable jewellery

Minimum age is 13 years. This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including photography, pottery, animation and sewing head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.

description:
How To Be A DJ - An Introduction, Always wanted to try being a DJ but not sure where to begin? Experienced and professional DJ Shan (Shannon Chng-Rawiri) will teach you all about the technical aspects, equipment and terminology, as well as the industry in general, and enable you to put together a confident short performance.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

Gain an understanding of the work content and career opportunities in this industry
- Learn the difference between what a DJ is required to deliver in the following situations: Mobile, Club, Radio, Turntablist and Hobby
- Participate in various practical activities: Slip Cueing and Baby Scratch, basic beat matching and song structures

Gain a good understanding of the equipment used and terminology including:
Tables: pitch control
Mixer: crossfader, input faders, EQ, gain, cue system
Needles: back tracking
Slip Mats

Learn about Counting Bars and Matching Tempos - The difference between a Bar, Phrases and BPM - Techniques to Count, Hand position and movement etc
- Confidently present a 5 minute performance in class

The course will be held at DJ Shan’s studio at Shop 21, 71 Cuba Street, Wellington. Bring headphones, a USB with your favourite music and a laptop, if you have one. Limited to eight participants.. Bring headphones, a USB with your favourite music and a laptop, if you have one. Limited to eight participants.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Duration 6 weeks,
DJ Shan

description:
British and Irish Film Festival - The History of Sound, - OFFICIAL SELECTION: Festival de Cannes 2025 -

Based on the acclaimed book by Ben Shattuck, Paul Mescal (Aftersun, All of Us Strangers) and Josh O’Connor (The Crown, Challengers) play star-crossed lovers in this sweeping, moving and tender romance from Oliver Hermanus (Living).

In 1917, Lionel (Mescal) — a young, talented music student — meets David (O’Connor) at the Boston Conservatory, where they bond over a deep love of folk music.

Years later, Lionel receives a letter from David, leading to an impromptu journey through the backwoods of Maine to collect traditional songs. This unexpected reunion, ensuing love affair, and the music they collect and preserve, will shape the course of Lionel’s life far beyond his own awareness.

Paul Mescal and Josh O’Connor’s star turns received rave reviews when The History of Sound premiered at the Cannes Film Festival earlier this year, making this quiet but powerful drama a must-see at the British and Irish Film Festival 2025.
Rating
Sex scenes & suicide references
Director
Oliver Hermanus
Cast
Paul Mescal, Josh O’Connor, Chris Cooper
label: Film & Media

description:
Aunty Records Presents: Mark Farina [USA] with Benny Salvador, Aunty Records Presents: Mark Farina [USA] with Benny Salvador
Get ready, Wellington—one of the most influential figures in house music is landing in the capital for a night of deep grooves, soulful rhythms, and undeniable dancefloor magic at Meow NUI.

===Tickets on sale Friday 22 August at 12.00PM====

Mark Farina is a global dance music icon whose name resonates across the scene. Known for his Mushroom Jazz series, deep house sets, and marathon all-night performances, Farina has built a career on innovation, consistency, and a relentless touring schedule of over 100 shows a year. He has collaborated with legendary venues and record labels, showcasing both classic and new school producers in his sets.

With his recent YouTube series with Defected Records and continued worldwide performances, Farina connects with both longtime fans and new audiences alike, delivering unforgettable journeys through house, jazz-infused grooves, and eclectic beats.

Supporting him is Wellington’s Benny Salvador — one of New Zealand’s most exciting young talents. A DJ, producer, multi-instrumentalist, radio host, and event promoter, Benny has shared stages with Marcellus Pittman and Courtesy and played major festivals including Splore, Beacon, and Catacombs. He has recorded mixes for Planet Trip Records, NTS, Balamii, Related Articles, and Friendly Potential Radio, and released music on Racquet Club, Rush Hour, Love Above Records, Juke Bounce Werk, and his own Aunty Records. Benny’s eclectic sets blend house, techno, disco-funk, dub, and electro, drawing on jazz and funk influences while showcasing his crate-digging, collaborative approach.

This is a rare chance to experience two generations of dance music mastery under one roof. From Farina’s world-renowned grooves to Benny’s forward-thinking, genre-spanning sets, the night promises a journey through sound that will move the floor and leave a lasting impression. For fans of house, jazz-infused beats, and cutting-edge underground sounds, this is a must-attend event at Meow Nui.

Saturday 18th October
Doors 9:30 PM

description:
Queer Horizons presents Hot Mooch, Hot Mooch is a queer club night. Come to shake up koanga with a night of hot dance music. 
Spawned from the legendary Queer Horizons in Ōtautahi Christchurch, Hot Mooch is happening in te Upoko o te Ika Wellington - Valhalla to be exact - on 11 October. 
!!! THIS LINEUP !!!
🎶 DJ Thank U So Much (Te Whanganui-a-Tara)
🎶 Mr Meaty Boy (Ōtautahi)
🎶 AAKI (Ōtautahi)
🎶 Oil Grace (Tāmaki Makaurau)
Come to kanikani. Toi tū te Tiriti and free Palestine.
About Hot Mooch
Hot Mooch is for the bipoc and queer communities of Te Whanganui-a-Tara and their allies. It is intended as a night to dance and listen to loud music: in safety, as yourself, and with abandon. 
BIPOC and LGBTQIA+ front and centre: always.
Tino rangatiratanga: mō āke tonu atu.
FREE PALESTINE. 10% of sales go to Team Assal for their work supporting people in Gaza.
The night is dedicated to respectful, inclusive, and joyful space: we have no tolerance for any unsafe behaviour including racism, ableism, sexism, homophobia, transphobia, xenophobia, fatphobia, or unwanted attention. 
Show lots of love and respect to our amazing performers and DJs and give them space to do their thing.
Take care of those around you, be aware of the space you inhabit and respect the needs of others. Ear plugs are available at the bar, and we encourage you to take time out, and check in with your friends. If you need help please ask the bar staff or organisers. 
  Accessibility details
Valhalla is wheelchair accessible with accessible toilets. If you have other accessibility needs, DM Abby on Insta @emmanuelcunnane

description:
Commodores in Wellington, Commodores in Wellington

🎶 Don't Miss Commodores Live in Wellington on Tuesday, October 21, 2025! 🎶
Are you ready to experience Commodores like never before? With chart-topping hits like Easy, Brick House and Nightshift and 1.8M+ devoted fans, Commodores is taking over St James Theatre Wellington this Tuesday, October 21, 2025, and trust us, you don't want to miss this.

With multiple shows lined up, this one ensures to be the ultimate musical experience, where the energy of Commodores will make you dance, sing, and maybe even cry (in a good way).

Event Details:

📅 Date: Tuesday, October 21, 2025
⏰ Time: 8:00 PM
📍 Venue: St James Theatre Wellington

Expect an unforgettable performance featuring all your favorite songs and some surprises you've never heard before. So, If you're discovering Commodores for the first time, this show will blow your mind.

Why This Show is Unmissable
With over 6.8M+ fans streaming their music monthly and viral singles in every playlist, Commodores is at the peak of their career. If you're a long-time fan or just love the buzz, this show will be one for the books.

P.S. – You don't want to be that person who hears about it later! We will not let you miss this in any way!🎉

Artist's Power Move
Commodores has been setting the stage on fire with performances that leave fans begging for more. With an incredible setlist and live versions of your favorite songs, you'll leave with stories to tell (and maybe a few epic selfies). Follow Commodores on AllEvents to get hyped for the event!

🎟️ Book Your Tickets Now! 🎟️
This is your chance to witness Commodores live and in their element. Grab your tickets now for Commodores in Wellington at St James Theatre Wellington and be part of a night that everyone will be talking about. Don't wait—tickets are selling fast.

description:
Paint Time with Rapunzel, Paint Time with Rapunzel
Join Rapunzel for a magical painting session where young artists will create their own flower-filled canvas masterpiece!

Paint Time with Rapunzel

👑 Meet & greet photos with Rapunzel

description:
Wellington Timebank Spring Clothes Swap!, All welcome!
Wellington Timebank will be hosting a fun social event for Spring - a clothes swap! Come along to meet and hang out with other Timebank members, and take this opportunity to sustainably refresh and/or clear out your wardrobe for Spring!
Sunday 19 October
10am-1.30pm
Te Aro Zero Waste Centre
2 Forresters Lane, Te Aro
--
How it works:
10am-11am:
Drop off your clothes/accessories etc to swap (washed and in good condition please!).
We welcome clothes and accessories from/for everyone - including kids clothes and pet clothes (?)!
~ Have a hot drink while our team sort out the clothes
~
11.30am-1.30pm:
Swap is open! Go and get yourself a whole new wardrobe!
--
Timebankers receive 1 time credit for bringing clothes, or spend 1 time credit to pick up some new (to you) clothes (if you do both, it's free!).
Non-timebankers can attend for koha, so please feel free to bring your friends and whānau. And encourage them to join the Timebank
All clothing remaining after the swap will be donated to charity op-shops - Aunty Dana's and Opportunity for Animals.
If you would like to do some baking or volunteer (we need some clothes sorters!) for this event, your support would be very much appreciated! Please send me a message/email me on info@wellingtontimebank.org.nz.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Playgroup and Preschool Open Day, Playgroup and Preschool Open Day
Nau mai, haere mai!

We are excited to be holding an Open Day this term for families interested in finding out more about our Playgroup and Preschool (caregivers interested in other areas welcome too!).

Wā Ora is the only Montessori school in New Zealand that caters for children from playgroup through to Year 13. Mark the date in your diary and pop in to see our Montessori playgroup, preschool and primary environment. Teachers and current parents will also be available to chat. There will also be a sausage sizzle for hungry tummies.

More information about our school is available on our website, or if you have any questions, please feel free to contact . We look forward to sharing the benefits of Montessori for your child with you soon!

description:
Funky Fridays Vol.7 - Not My Sister, Libbi K, Ben-Jammin, Funky Fridays Vol.7 - Not My Sister, Libbi K, Ben-Jammin
We're back for another night of house techno disco bass & more at Moon with Funky Fridays Vol. 7!
Created to revive and celebrate the underground electronic scene Funky Friday is more than just a night out—it’s a space for music lovers dancers and creatives to connect through rhythm and energy. Each edition features a rotating lineup of talented DJs both local and international ensuring a fresh and unique experience every time.
Come with an open mind and leave with tired feet.
This edition features legends Libby K Ben-Jammin & our host Not My Sister!
$10 presales available now via UTR or $15 on the door.
Times:
9-10 Not My Sister
10-11.30 Libby K
11.30-1 Ben Jammin
1-2 Not My Sister
-------------------------------------------------------
NOT MY SISTER
Not My Sister is a house music DJ born and raised in a little town in the north of Italy. Now based in Wellington she started this project in 2024 and recently she has been lighting up dance floors across New Zealand you may have already come across her sets at Twisted Frequency Kiwiburn Earthbeat Cuba Dupa Arkadien and other events across the country. Influenced by funk and disco with a special focus on vocals and anything groovy Not My Sister brings high energy and uplifting sets. Constantly developing as an artist she always brings fun and passion to the dance floors. Expect a delightful fusion of melodic basslines blending soulful tech garage and deep house sounds.
www.soundcloud.com/not-my-sister
www.facebook.com/notmysista
www.instangram.com/not.my.sister

LIBBY K
From the vibrant streets of Wellington Libby's fascination with music began at an early age with the smooth sultry
sounds of the clarinet and piano. Fast forward to her 20s where she stumbled into the hypnotic world of techno in
Berlin and a passion for 4/4 was ignited.
With a deep appreciation for the power of music to transform Libby finds the greatest joy on a dance floor where
the magic of music brings people together and gives us the freedom to be ourselves. Her sets are filled with
uplifting emotive and tantalising sounds of downtempo house and techno. Mixed with intention and a whole lot
of love **
https://soundcloud.com/libby_k
https://www.instagram.com/libbykdj/
https://www.facebook.com/libbykmusic
https://www.twitch.tv/libbykdj

BEN-JAMMIN
Originally from Bristol UK Ben was immersed in soundsystem culture from an early age. He started collecting vinyl in his teens and developed a passion for the heavier side of electronic music. With his formative years spent mixing vinyl studying African percussion and playing drums and recording for rock/rap group Band of Crooks he moved on to play with some of the best underground DJ's producers and musicians in Aotearoa Australia and UK. Ben has played a myriad of parties and events including Newtown Festival Cuba Dupa Kiwi Burn Little Monsters Insomnia Toots Suite Festival (Salmonella Dub Laughton Kora Pheonix Foundation) Breakaway Magical Doof Bus (Paige Julia Y SorchalulaYoung Gho$t House MD) Cuba Dupa Sydney Rd Street Festival (Melbourne) Cafe Blue (UK) Castros (UK).
Ben-Jammin can do what is needed to keep a dancefloor alive comfortably switching between genres to suit the mood.
Always armed with bags of bass heavy treats expect a selection of new classic and surprise music to help you release your spirit into the world.

description:
Te Wā o Te Kōanga - Spring Festival, Te Wā o te Kōanga | Spring Festival 2025
It’s time to shake off the winter blues and celebrate kōanga/spring at Wellington Gardens!

Join us throughout September for Te Wā o te Kōanga, a month-long festival bursting with flowers, fresh beginnings, and lots of ways to connect with nature and community.
Explore both Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā and Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush with events for everyone — from self-drive floral tours and roaming performers, to interactive family fun, art exhibitions, and behind-the-scenes experiences.

Bring your friends, whānau, and neighbours to celebrate the season of new life in Aotearoa’s special native and cultivated gardens.
Stay tuned for event highlights and come discover the joy of kōanga!

description:
Men's Circle: Honest Conversations & Connection, Men's Circle: Honest Conversations & Connection
Men’s Circle: Honest Conversations & Connection

In a world where men are often expected to have everything figured out, this gathering offers a space to be genuine, not perfect.

This is a free event, with an optional plant-based dinner available for $15. While there’s no obligation to stay for dinner, sharing a meal together offers a meaningful way to strengthen connections. Andre and Sri Jiva co-host this circle with a shared passion for creating authentic, supportive spaces where men can connect deeply—offering this gathering simply because they believe in its importance.

The Men’s Circle provides a safe and nurturing environment where men can share openly, express their feelings, and encourage personal growth—free from societal pressures to be stoic or self-reliant. Through honest sharing and collective support, participants build resilience, deepen self-awareness, and strengthen their sense of identity and purpose.

Structure of the Circle

Gathering in a Circle: Participants sit in a circle to symbolize equality and unity.

A short meditation or moment of silence may be included to help everyone arrive and connect.

Talking Object: A sharing stick or object is placed in the center. Only the person holding the object may speak, ensuring uninterrupted sharing.

Open Sharing: Anyone may choose to share while holding the object. Sharing is optional, and passing is always respected.

Active Listening: While one person shares, others listen attentively without speaking, interrupting, or offering advice. The focus is on witnessing and being present.

No Judgments or Advice: Participants refrain from judging or offering unsolicited advice, creating a safe space for authentic expression.

Closing: The circle may conclude with a group reflection, a moment of gratitude, or a simple acknowledgment of the shared experience.

Circle Agreements

Supportive Environment: We are here to uplift and support one another, fostering trust and brotherhood.

Focus on the Present: Share what's alive for you now, focusing on your emotions and experiences to deepen emotional awareness.

Use "I" Statements: Speak from your personal perspective using "I" statements to promote authenticity and responsibility. Avoid generalizations like "we" or "us."

No Judgment or fixing: Refrain from judging others sharing or offering unsolicited advice, ensuring a safe and non-critical space.

Confidentiality: What is shared in the circle stays in the circle. You may discuss your own experience outside the group, but keep others' details private.

Meet Andre and Sri Jiva, your hosts

Andre has been immersed in men’s work since the age of 13, when he first experienced a rite of passage in Golden Bay. That formative experience sparked a lifelong connection to circle work, which he later deepened by returning as a mentor. A multi-instrumental musician, poet, and pranayama (breathwork) facilitator, Andre also brings his passion for ecstatic dance, philosophy, and authentic connection into his offerings. He is deeply inspired by the question of what it means to be human—how we can more fully experience our aliveness, our depth, and reconnecting with the beauty of life together.

Since childhood, Sri Jiva has been fascinated by meaning, purpose, and authentic life fulfilment. This, among other things, led him to join a monastery at the age of 19. After years of monastic training, he chose to marry and pursue a career. He felt called to use his monastic experience to help others understand themselves, and to find wisdom, meaning, and purpose in their own lives. Inspired by this calling, he went to university to study counselling. Now, Sri Jiva and his wife live near Wellington, where he works with a small team of counsellors, supporting clients individually and in groups.

description:
Amanda Bunting and Kris Zuelicke, Solos and Duets for Piano, Leo Smit - Divertimento

Ginastera - No. 2 from Danzas Argentinas, op. 2 - "Danza de la moza donosa"

Ravel - Sonatine, M. 40, Movement I - Modéré

Schubert - "Lebensstürme," Allegro in A minor, D 947

Amanda Bunting is a graduate of the New Zealand School of Music, completing her Bachelor of Music with Honours in 2019 in solo piano performance with Dr. Jian Liu; small group ensemble with Dr. Rolf Gjelsten; and performance and embodiment studies with Dr. Hamish Robb and Dr. Margaret Medlyn. Prior to that, she completed a Graduate Diploma in Music in performance piano, performance studies, and pedagogy.

After previously studying with Gillian Bibby at the Conservatorium of Music and graduating in 1996, Amanda chose to return to study to further develop performance skills, enhance her own piano performance abilities and to gain further knowledge that can be shared with her piano students. Amanda is an Associate of the Institute of Registered Music Teachers New Zealand, a member of the Wellington Branch and currently works both as a Piano Teacher and a Human Resources Adviser at Victoria University of Wellington.

Kris Zuelicke grew up in a theatrical and musical family, accompanying shows and choirs from high school onwards. In the USA, she gained degrees in Music (BA Miami University) and Music Theory (MA Indiana University) and taught music along with other subjects at the Bloomington Montessori School.

In Karlsruhe, Germany Kris taught at the Landau Montessori School, Berlitz Language School, courses on theatre and music at the Teacher’s College and piano privately. She studied with Annemi Egri and Sariel Maler during this time.

Kris currently teaches in five schools around Wellington, maintains a thriving private piano and cello studio and accompanies students at the New Zealand School of Music. Her most recent degree is in harpsichord performance (DMA NZSM), including study and research in Boston with Mark Kroll. Kris enjoys performing regularly with other musicians, including piano duets, chamber music and has enjoyed projects with Stroma, the Queen’s Closet and a fun stint as a harpsichordist extra in the recently released Time Bandits.
