description:
Mystery Feast on Mischief Night! Halloween dinner with Chef Max Gordy
Supporting Kaibosh., Step inside, if you dare... on the eve of Halloween. It's a Mischief Night!
A chilling murder mystery unfolds over a hauntingly good three-course Halloween dinner by Chef Max Gordy!
On 30 October, gather your cleverest friends and find your darkest ghoulish attire
Who will crack the case first: the Detectives or the Villains?

Expect twists, laughter, and a touch of fright
with spot prizes through the night — plus a reward for the best-dressed.
Award-winning chef Max Gordy ( @grazewinebar ) will conjure up a frightfully delicious Halloween-themed feast.
Your ticket includes one complimentary alcoholic beverage (with more available to purchase on the night).
Every ticket sold helps Kaibosh ensure that no good food is left to die.
TICKET TYPES
Bring a team of six to solve the mystery and devour a fiendishly good feast for $666.
Have a frightening four-some? Book a table for $444.
Spooky single seats available for $111... we will seat you at a mystery table...
VENUE
60 Dixon Street is up a flight of steep steps – with only one way in.
What is Mischief Night?
In parts of Pennsylvania and New Jersey in the eastern USA, 30 October is called “Mischief Night.” The tradition refers to the eve of Halloween in which children and teenagers celebrate the holiday one night early with pranks, tricks and more. While in New England, some call it Cabbage Night...
label: Food & Drink

description:
Advice for Modern Life - meditation course, Advice for Modern Life - meditation course
Advice for Modern Life - meditation course
with Kadam Birgit

By keeping Atisha’s Advice in our heart, we can maintain a peaceful happy mind, our human nature and good qualities will improve, we will be able to show a good example for the people of our troubled world and we will quickly attain full enlightenment.

As Venerable Geshe-la says, ‘Simply putting this Advice into practice we will naturally become a Bodhisattva, a holy compassionate being who is the object of everybody’s love and respect’.

On this half day course Kadam Birgit will share teachings given at the International Summer Festival 2025 on Advice from Atisha’s Heart.

Although it was composed many centuries ago, this much-loved Buddhist scripture is full of practical advice to help us deal with the challenges of modern living, and transform our life into an authentic path of inner development.

Everyone welcome.

WHAT TO EXPECT
These classes are based on Buddha’s teachings on the mind, but you do not need to be a Buddhist to attend, or to benefit from them. There is no physical exercise involved and you can choose to sit either in a chair or on a cushion. These classes are suitable for all levels of experience.

Registration starts at 9:30am. This course includes a vegan, wheat-free morning tea (we cannot guarantee gluten-free).
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Netherfield Ball, Step into the enchanting world of Jane Austen’s Pride and Prejudice at Homewood, where the timeless elegance of a Regency-era ball comes to life. This evening of romance, music, and culinary delight invites you to relive the iconic moments of Elizabeth Bennet and Mr Darcy’s fateful meeting.

Guests will be greeted with crafted cocktails inspired by love potions, showcasing ingredients from some of the finest distilleries in New Zealand and the United Kingdom. As the evening unfolds, indulge in a carefully curated selection of canapés, created with fresh ingredients sourced from Homewood’s own garden, evoking the flavours and charm of the Regency period.

The grand setting of Homewood, the esteemed residence of the British High Commissioner, will transport you to a bygone era. With the glow of garden lighting, live music filling the air, and an atmosphere brimming with romance, you’ll feel as if you’ve stepped into Austen’s world. Dancing will play a central role in the evening, allowing guests to immerse themselves in the grace and grandeur of the Regency social scene.

Whether you’re an Austen devotee, a fan of Bridgerton, or simply drawn to the allure of historical elegance, this event promises to captivate your imagination and senses. Don’t miss this rare opportunity to be part of a night filled with charm, sophistication, and timeless romance.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Nutcracker High Tea, QTea twirls into a sun-drenched daydream with a high tea inspired by The Nutcracker. In partnership with the Royal New Zealand Ballet, we’re serving a festive fairytale where Christmas meets choreography – with a Kiwiana twist.

Perched above the harbour, QTea High Tea reimagines its plated treats into a sugar plum dreamland. Think raspberry-layered delights, golden pistachio choux, smoked salmon cups and piroshki that dance on the palate.

Sip in style and cheers to the season with The Mouse King’s Toast, Prosecco and Guignolet fizzing with festive sparkle. Craving something a little nuttier? Try The Storm Master’s Tipple. For pure summer magic in a glass, reach for the Sugar Plum Fairy Fizz.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Nyumbani: A Taste of Tanzania, Journey through the heart of Tanzania with dishes that feel like home - comforting, bold, and full of love. This special five-course degustation is created by Chef Shuchi Bhardwaj, a baker who grew up in Tanzania and carries its flavours, traditions, and warmth in her heart. 
Whether it’s the warm embrace of coconut-infused stews, smoky grilled meats, or fragrant spiced rice, each course is a reminder of how food connects us. This menu brings authentic East African flavours to the table, reimagined in a modern way that feels like home. Each course is matched with a carefully selected wine to enhance the flavours of the dish. Expect generous hospitality and a setting that feels like stepping into a Tanzanian family gathering.
label: Food & Drink

description:
E-Waste Drop off Day Zealandia, Drop off your unwanted electronic products during this drive-thru event!
Held in the lower "overflow' carpark of the Zealandia - on the corner of Birchwood Street.
Please check the posts in 'discussion' for more details.
Staff will unload everything for your convenience.
We are proud to accept donations for Variety – the Children’s Charity.
FREE OF CHARGE
Computers, Monitors, Tablets and Small Devices, Laptops, Routers and Modems, Mice, Servers, UPS, Cameras, Hifi Stereo Amps and Speakers, Mobile Phones, Car Batteries, Wiring & Cabling, Mainframe Circuit Boards, etc.
CHARGED ITEMS:
• $2 Fluorescent Tubes (Normal Light bulbs not accepted)
• $3 for Media and DVD player, Keyboards, Toner Cartridges, Desk phones
• $5 per kg - Mixed Batteries
• $5 for Heaters, Microwaves, Vacuum Cleaners, AV Equipment, Small Home Appliances
• $10 for Printers, Scanners, Fax Machines
• $20 Dishwashers, Washing Machines, Dryers, Flat screen TVs
• $40 Fridges, Heatpumps and Air Con units
• $60 Large Photocopiers
Please understand charges above are for sharing the recycling cost.
Eftpos and cash accepted on site.
What we don't accept:
- CDs & DVDs
- Floppy discs
- LED lightbulbs
- Household lightbulbs
- LPG gas bottle
- Medical devices
- Glass
Other hazardous waste (e.g.)
- Paint
- Garden waste
- General chemicals
- Furniture (e.g.)
- TV cabinets

description:
Pre order Thai foods, NEXT WEEK'S THAI COMFORT SPECIAL IS HERE!

Get ready for our Kin Favorite: Beef Mince Pad Kaprao with Fried Egg
!
This is the ultimate Thai street food classic, and here's why you need to pre-order:
Tender, savory beef mince is wok-tossed with a fiery, fragrant blend of fresh chilies, garlic, and aromatic fresh basil. The high heat of the wok creates a spicy-sweet, intensely savory glaze that is totally addictive.
Served hot over jasmine rice and crowned with a crispy-edged, runny-yolked fried egg. Break that yolk and mix it all together for a bite of pure happiness!
PLUS! Our signature Chicken or Tofu Satay is still on the menu for the perfect side.
Delivery Dates:
Dinner: Wednesday, October 8th
Lunch: Friday, October 10th
Order Cut-Off: Monday, October 6th, 9 PM
Pre-order now to secure your Thai feast!

description:
Ziggy Alberts tickets, Presented by: Commonfolk
ARIA-accredited and APRA Award-winning artist Ziggy Alberts will return to New Zealand this November as part of his New Love World Tour, following three years of extensive touring across Europe, the UK, North and South America, Asia, and regional Australia. Celebrating the release of his seventh studio album, New Love, Ziggy will return to New Zealand for the first time since 2023, with three special shows in Christchurch, Wellington, and Auckland.
From his early days busking the streets of Byron Bay to selling out venues like London’s Royal Albert Hall, Ziggy’s journey has been defined by grassroots touring, heartfelt songwriting, and an unwavering independent spirit.
The New Zealand leg of the tour kicks off on Thursday 13 November at Christchurch Town Hall, followed by Meow Nui in Wellington on Friday 14 November, and concludes at Auckland’s Powerstation on Saturday 15 November. This tour will showcase Ziggy’s signature solo style - spirited, raw, and deeply authentic - the kind of direct connection that has earned him over one billion streams, multiple awards, and a loyal global fanbase.
Fans can look forward to favourites like ‘Days in the Sun’ and ‘Runaway’, which recently surpassed 100 million streams, alongside new tracks from New Love - an album crafted for live performance. Featuring hit singles 'New Love’, 'Where Does the Love Go?' and latest single, ‘I’m With You’ the record marks a return to simplicity and authenticity, blending folk, rock, and country influences to create a cohesive yet dynamic listening experience.
Alberts’ year of New Love is not one to miss. This leg of the world tour will celebrate connection, authenticity, and music’s ability to bring people together. Don’t miss the chance to see Ziggy Alberts live on the New Love World Tour 2025

Rotten Luck Fermentation Club Special SAUERKRAUT & KIMCHI (Kids)– Pop-up Parlour 2025, Rotten Luck Fermentation Club Special SAUERKRAUT & KIMCHI (Kids)– Pop-up Parlour 2025
The Rotten Luck Club is at the Pop-up Parlour!

SAUERKRAUT & KIMCHI - SCHOOL HOLIDAY EDITION

Learn how to make kimchi and sauerkraut with locals Kelly and Catherine from Pukerua Bay Fermentation Club. This will be a hands on session!

Event Details

• What - 2 hr workshop
• When - 11am-1pm, 23 September 2025
• Where - St Marks, 98 Rāwhiti Road, Pukerua Bay (opposite school)
• Cost - $10 per person and you will head away with jars of beautiful kimchi and sauerkraut to continue the fermentation process at home. Salt, sugar and fish sauce and gochugaru chilli flakes for kimchi and caraway seeds for the sauerkraut will be supplied.

BOOK NOW https://tinyurl.com/4hdapf3b

• What to bring? BYO knife, wooden spoon, chopping board, big mixing pot/bowl and glass jars! If everyone contributes a couple fresh vege/fruit ingredients to share, we will have some options to play with on the day (e.g. Green/red/Savoy/Chinese cabbage - Daikon/Chinese radish - Red chilies - Apple - Mushrooms - Carrot - Beets - Cucumber- Ginger - Onion - Garlic - Garden greens like kale, bok choy, spinach).

• Who - Kids encouraged to join but must be supervised by a caregiver at all times and will need their own ticket.

Other Rotten Luck Fermentation Club events at the Pop-up:

- Sauerkraut & Kimchi (Rangatahi & Adults) $10. https://tinyurl.com/7myhk5v9
- Bread-making $10 https://tinyurl.com/yfkderv7
- Recipe Discovery @ PKB Library, free https://tinyurl.com/byswfp93
- Whiskey-making @RSA $20 https://tinyurl.com/2a26z3yt
- Cheese-making $10 https://tinyurl.com/5n7twce7

All paid events are helping to fundraise for the Pop-up Parlour.

description:
Saturday 'BAKES' By Onslow College, Each Saturday, we offer a variety of sourdough products next to Onslow College. We always have doughnuts, but on Saturdays we offer bread, savoury baked items (this Saturday, we have brioche), and mini-celebratory sourdough doughnuts.
All products can be pre-ordered and picked up on Saturday morning through our website.
https://familykitchenwithmark.co.nz/weekly-menu/
EFTPOS is always available.
Our boxed mini-celebratory doughnuts, 70% of the original size, are available for a sale price of $25 for a box of all six flavours.
Our regular doughnuts cost $6 each or $22 for a box of 4 doughnuts.
We also offer catering at Family Kitchen with Mark, so if you have a function or need for in-house dining, check out all our packages on our website. Our doughnuts are also available for purchase all week. Contact Mark on 021 0223 0824 for next-day pickup.
https://familykitchenwithmark.co.nz/grazing-tables-theme.../
All our doughnuts contain a lively sourdough & biga starter, for a fuller flavour profile and a springy texture.
Have you tried our sourdough doughnuts yet?
Our doughnuts can be pre-ordered and picked up on the day to avoid disappointment (should we run out).
We launch a new flavour every two weeks and have created over 180 combinations since selling three years ago.
Support has been phenomenal, and we thank everyone so very much indeed for the weekly sales.
If you are not following us on our social media channels, please consider doing so, as it helps the company grow and increases the exposure of our products. Thank you.

https://familykitchenwithmark.co.nz/grazing-tables-theme.../
All our doughnuts contain a lively sourdough & biga starter, for a fuller flavour profile and a springy texture.
Have you tried our sourdough doughnuts yet?
Our doughnuts can be pre-ordered and picked up on the day to avoid disappointment (should we run out).
We launch a new flavour every two weeks and have created over 180 combinations since selling three years ago.
Support has been phenomenal, and we thank everyone so very much indeed for the weekly sales.
If you are not following us on our social media channels, please consider doing so, as it helps the company grow and increases the exposure of our products. Thank you.

Then head next door for a guided wine tasting from the passionate team at The Good Way (located beside the Martinborough Brewery on Ohio Street), showcasing a selection of their elegant, small-batch wines. Auckland based jazz ensemble Stable Mates Sextet performs a selection of original compositions inspired by an array of influences, ranging from Wayne Shorter and Pharoah Sanders to Michael Brecker and Chris Potter. Having performed together regularly fronted by individual bandleaders in the past, the Stable Mates Sextet now joins forces as a collaborative group ready to share new works, and new interpretations of old works.

description:
Silencing the Inner Critic - meditation course, Silencing the Inner Critic - meditation course
Silencing the Inner Critic - meditation course
with Kadam Birgit

We can easily develop the unhelpful habit of harsh self-criticism, disturbing our mental peace and holding us back from being the person we want to be.
Learn to recognise this inner critic as it operates in your life and relationships and discover through meditation how to let go of this painful habit.

At this workshop, Kadam Birgit will guide us in practical and effective meditations and ways of thinking, that enable us to become happier, more content and comfortable in our self and our life.

WHAT TO EXPECT
These classes are based on Buddha’s teachings on the mind, but you do not need to be a Buddhist to attend, or to benefit from them. There is no physical exercise involved and you can choose to sit either in a chair or on a cushion. These classes are suitable for all levels of experience.

Registration starts at 9:30am. This course includes a vegan, wheat-free morning tea (we cannot guarantee gluten-free).
label: Health & Wellness

Spy in the Wild, Step into a world of mystery, flavour, and espionage at The Green Man Pub on Wednesday, 23rd October.
Doors open at 6:00pm, with the main event kicking off at 6:30pm. You’ll be welcomed with a sealed mission envelope containing your assignment for the evening. In teams, you’ll work to crack codes, decipher tasting notes, and unravel clues inspired by Spy Valley’s wines and the stories behind them.
Along the way, enjoy five chef-crafted canapés, each perfectly matched with a hand-picked Spy Valley wine. Expect a captivating atmosphere enhanced by lasers and special effects, transforming the pub into a true espionage experience.

description:
Dia de los Muertos - Day of the Dead Celebration with Claudio Escutia, Dia de los Muertos - Day of the Dead Celebration with Claudio Escutia
Join Claudio for this special occasion we will be celebrating one of the most important holidays in Mexico, the day of the dead or “Dia de los Muertos”.

The Day of the Dead is one of the traditions that has remained alive throughout the centuries; the main holidays are November 1 & 2, which UNESCO designated and cataloged as an Intangible Heritage of Humanity in 2003.

This special celebration dates back to prehispanic times before the arrival of Europeans to America, and has been alive and widely celebrated over the years.

About the Day of the Dead
The Day of the Dead tradition dates back to pre-Hispanic times, when a tribute was paid to death; the tribute took place from the last week of October to the first days of November.

Prehispanic Mexicans conceived Death as the beginning of the journey to Mictlán (the Place of the Dead), during which the soul of the deceased had to overcome various obstacles before reaching Mictlantecuhtli (the Lord of the Dead) and Mictecacíhuatl (the Lady of the Dead). Upon reaching the gods of Mictlán, an offering had to be made to them in order to obtain eternal rest.

What to Expect
Claudio will explain why it is important to celebrate and take the time to honour and remember the members of your family, ancestors and loved ones who have passed away. He will also explain the mysticism and spirituality around the Day of the Dead celebration.

We’ll also learn how to set up your ofrenda, or altar, and which elements are important for it (as well their meaning).

It's very common for an ofrenda of the dead to be placed inside Mexican homes, decorated with papel picado, food, traditional sweets, and photos of loved ones. Candles and marigold flowers are also placed as a sign of welcome for our loved ones.

Feel free to bring photos of your beloved ones that have passed away, fruits and flowers for the altar and anything that your beloved ones valued / loved when they were here with us. We will place those on the altar.

The Evening’s Schedule
Cleansing copal and herbal welcoming.

An opening ceremony to acknowledge the Tlalmanalli (offering and altar) with the deep sound of the conch shell in the four directions and drums sounds.

History of the day of the dead celebration.

Explanation of the altar, and the main elements for an ofrenda.

Storytelling: learn of Mexican legends like Catrinas and Xoloitzcuintle (the Mexican dog that helps the dead to find their way to Mictlan, the Aztec underword).

Remembering and sharing histories about the loved ones that passed away (optional but encouraged)

Traditional Mexican chants for remembering the loved ones

Atole de Chocolate, a traditional prehispanic drink - amazing in flavour, consumed cold or hot

Music to invoke emotion and imagery of contemplative natural and mystical environments

Finish with a shamanic atmosphere of relaxation and traditional chants.

Details
When: Saturday 1 November, 7pm -9pm

Where: AWHI Yoga & Wellbeing - Level 2, 15 Johnston Street, Wellington CBD.

Investment: $55 (first 5 enrolments - $45!); Children under 16 years old - $35

Haere Mai!
Everyone is welcome including kids (see special pricing). No previous experience or knowledge is required. As this is an evening of learning and exploration, come wearing comfortable clothing! Bring an open heart and mind willing to learn and receive.

description: Sweet Sensations, Noble Rot wants to sing the praises of sweet wines and help you to learn that they aren't just one note. They'll showcase a range of wines from around the world that lean towards the sweeter side without leaving a cloying sensation on your palate, enhanced by a specially-curated five-course degustation menu from entree to dessert. If you would like to explore your favourite level of sweetness in wine, this event is for you. The knowledgeable Noble Rot team are here to show you that sweetness is one of wine’s most versatile assets, as well-balanced sweetness in wine can be delicate, elegant and complementary to both sweet and savoury dishes. Discover how some grape varieties are more suited to producing sweeter wines and how their level of sweetness is achieved. If you're into the sweeter things in life, this one is for you.

description:
Painted Past: Tribute to the Heritage City of Ahmedabad, An exhibition Sandip Prajapati celebrating the architectural heritage of Ahmedabad, India.
Opening Hours
Tuesday - Saturday: 11am - 6pm
Sunday: 11am - 4pm
Ahmedabad, designated as a UNESCO World Heritage City in 2017, is renowned for its rich architectural heritage and cultural significance, showcasing a blend of Indo-Islamic architecture and vibrant local traditions.
Born in Patan, Gujarat, Sandip Prajapati has always been fascinated by the rich history and culture of the region.
An architect by profession, he uses his knowledge of design and structure to capture the essence of the pol houses. Pol houses are traditional residential buildings that are clustered around narrow streets and courtyards in the old city of Ahmedabad. They date back to the 18th century and reflect the influence of various communities and religions that coexisted in the city. Pol houses are known for their intricate wooden carvings, ornamental facades, and colorful decorations. They are also a living testimony of the social and harmony that prevailed in the city.
CONTACT
Website: sprajapati.com
Instagram: @sandipprajapati1

description:
The Casual Dram: 19, It’s time for another Casual Dram, and this time we’ll be taking a look at distillation rates - with double, partial-triple and triple distilled whiskies all making an appearance.
If you’ve ever looked at the flow chart for partial triple distillation, you’ll know that this sort of thing can be pretty complex!
But fear not, I promise we won’t be getting too scientific - and we’ll taste an interesting mix of official and independently bottled crackers, across a multitude of ages from some all-time fave distilleries; Mortlach, Benrinnes, Bunnahabhain and Amrut.
Here’s the lineup…
Bunnahabhain 12 years old 2023 Cask Strength Edition 60.1% (Sherry casks) WB 87.27
Mortlach 'Signatory Symington's Choice' 2007 / 17 years old #205 56.6% (1st Fill Oloroso Sherry Butt Finish) WB 88.23
Benrinnes Adelphi 13 years old 55.5% (1st Fill Oloroso Sherry Hogshead) WB 88.19
Amrut Triparva Triple Distilled 50% (casks as yet unknown) WB 87.19
Mystery whisky WB 88.11
I hope you can join me for another tilt at five tip top drams!

The Enchanted Ale Quarter, Enter the magical realm of The Enchanted Ale Quarter, a fairytale-inspired pop-up tavern where whimsy, wonder and craft beer collide.

Step into a storybook setting, with twinkling lights, woodland decor, and forest-fantasy touches around every corner. Feast on gnome and fairy-themed comfort food like the solstice salad, loaded forest fries, sirens & ships fish & chips, and a decadent dark forest brownie, all paired with enchanted brews and mythical tipples.

Cosy, curious, and otherworldly, The Enchanted Ale Quarter brings a little magic to Wellington’s winter nights. Dust off your wings and join us for a pint, some sustenance or a potion, no quest required.

description:
Traditional Kölsch Service!, Kölsch Service is BACK!! Enjoy our fresh batch of Dösen Kölsch the traditional way - just like in Köln.
What's Kölsch service?
It's kinda like beer yum cha but there's only one thing on the menu - 200ml glasses of Kölsch bier!

We keep track of your tab by marking the edge of your coaster and when your glass is empty - voilà, another glass appears!
If you're done, just pop your coaster on top of your glass to indicate no more.
You can order food and non-alcoholics the same way, just take a seat and everything will come to you.
To make sure you get a table, book here: https://www.meandoses.co.nz/bookings
PLUS DEUTSCHES ESSEN!

We're serving up Apache's take on Currywurst - the classic German streetfood that is a dream with a crisp Kölsch. Yes we'll sort some vegan ones too!
We're also slinging more amazing fresh Brezels
from Brezelmania, served with cheese sauce

We'll be running Kölsch service from 12pm - 5pm on Saturday October 4th, come along and get the Köln experience!
label: Food & Drink

description:
The Wellington Food Show, Are you ready to reignite your passion for cooking and get inspired with new flavours? Then look no further than The Food Show, Wellington's ultimate foodie extravaganza! This isn’t just another trip to the market — it’s an immersive culinary adventure that will excite all your senses.

Prepare to witness culinary rockstars in action as they whip up their signature dishes live! Renowned chefs and culinary stars, including MasterChef winners Nadia Lim, Sam Low, and the hilarious Annabelle White, will be sharing their tips, tricks, and insider knowledge in the Chance Voight Cooking Theatre. Whether you’re looking to master a new dish or get ideas to elevate your meals, this is your chance to get inspired and bring restaurant-worthy meals into your own kitchen.

Beyond the live cooking demonstrations, The Food Show is packed with exclusive show specials you won’t want to miss. Stock up on pantry essentials at unbeatable prices, discover hidden gems from local producers, or indulge in luxurious gourmet treats — all while saving big on products you can’t find anywhere else.

Whether you're a seasoned chef or just getting started, The Food Show is your ticket to discovering the best in food, flavour, and fun.

description:
Urban Cocktail Trail, On Sale Times
Presale Access - Thursday 31 July, 10am NZST
General Access - Thursday 31 July, 12pm NZST
----
Grab your mates and discover the best bars in Pōneke Wellington on the self-guided Urban Cocktail Trail! Whether you're a cocktail lover, or just up for a fun afternoon out, this trail is all about good drinks and great vibes!

Kick things off with a bite at your starting venue, then make your way around using your cocktail vouchers. Where you go and what you sip is totally up to you!

Tickets will fly, so lock yours in and get ready for an afternoon of flavour and fun!

VENUES + SIGNATURE COCKTAILS
1. Dirty Little Secret Ft. Peachy Pear
Absolut Pear Vodka + Vanilla Galliano + Peach Syrup + Lemon Juice + Egg White
2. Ernesto's Ft. Pimm'd to the Brim
Pimms + Cucumber Gin + Strawberry Liqueur + Juices
3. Otto Champagneria & Beer Hall Ft. Saigon Sunset
Papaiti Orchard Gin + Lemongrass Liqueur Syrup + Ginger Syrup + Lime Juice + Soda + Mint
4. Rosie's Red-Hot Cantina Ft. Coconut Margarita
Cazcabel Coconut Tequila + Triple Sec + Lime Juice + Agave Syrup
5. St John's Bar Ft. Tiki Trail
Sailor Jerry Spiced Rum + De Kuyper Banana Liqueur + De Kuyper Mango Liqueur + Kwai Feh + Lychee Liqueur + Lemon Juice + Pineapple Juice + Grenadine
6. The Old Bailey Ft. Pash & Dash
Rum + Passionfruit Liqueur + Passionfruit Syrup + Lime + Lemonade + Mint & Lime Garnish

TICKETS (Limited Availability)
Option #1 – The Connoisseur | $99
$10 Food Voucher for your chosen starting venue (valid until 2 PM)
6x Cocktail Vouchers to enjoy at any participating venue (valid until 5 PM)

Option #2 – The Trailblazer | $75
$10 Food Voucher for your chosen starting venue (valid until 2 PM)
4x Cocktail Vouchers to use at any participating venue (valid until 5 PM)
Note: Food options may vary from the venue’s regular menu due to the event format.

EVENT REGISTRATION & VOUCHER COLLECTION
Pick up your event vouchers and guide at the designated registration point before starting your trail.

Event Day Registration
Location: Ernesto's (1 Grey St, Te Aro)
Date: Saturday 6th September
Time: 12 PM – 1:30 PM

REFUND POLICY
Sorry no refunds, unless the event is cancelled/postponed by the organiser

GETTING AROUND
Aside from the amazing cocktails, one of the best things about the Urban Cocktail Trail is that it's a completely self-guided day out! What that means is once you've been to your nominated starting location you can go where you want, when you want!

Neighbourhood Events Co. recognises the unique role of Māori as Tangata Whenua and embraces Te Tiriti o Waitangi recognising Māori as Tino rangatiratanga of Aotearoa/New Zealand while embracing the three guiding principles of the Treaty – Partnership, Participation and Protection. We will endeavour to implement bicultural policies and practices that incorporate and value Māori cultural concepts, values and practices.

description:
Urban Wine Walk - Pōneke Wellington, The streets and laneways of Pōneke Wellington are set to come alive this Spring as a line-up of eight venues each play host to an incredible winemaker, who'll be there ready to pour and chat you through an unforgettable afternoon.


HOW IT WORKS

description:
Knitting for Beginners, Always wanted to learn how to knit but never been sure where to begin? Join craft tutor Stella Carruthers as she teaches the basic principles of knitting in this fun, informative and supportive class. Come along and learn the essential building blocks of knitting, using only knitting needles, yarn and your hands!
Come and reap the benefits of a mindful and meditative craft-form. Meet other people interested in making things with their hands, chat over crafting and find out what the craft craze is all about.

Join crafter Stella as she shares her ten years plus knitting experience in this beginner’s knitting class that supports each student as an individual learner.

Master basic knitting techniques, learn how to cast stitches on and off the needles, explore the knit and purl stitches and practice how to hold the needles in a way that is comfortable for you - then learn how to knit in the English style.

Knitting needles and yarn are included in the course fee, but you're welcome to bring along your own 4-ply yarn if you wish.

By the end of the course you will have created two squares of knitting, one in basic garter stitch and the other utilising both knit and purl stitches to create the knitted fabric called stocking stitch.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
A Very Wellington Sea Shanty Society Xmas, A Very Wellington Sea Shanty Society Xmas
NAUTICAL GAMES /// BEST DRESSED PRIZES /// SINGALONG SHANTIES /// XMAS-TYPE STUFF

Your work Xmas-party is going to be lame or cancelled so put a 2-dollar shop Santa's hat on 2025 and have a sing with Aotearoa's Most Seaworthy Shanty crew.

Prepare to be hit by a wave of joy and merriment as the Full Wellington Sea Shanty Society Experience transform the Abandoned Taproom into a shanty wonderland.

We got shanty booklets for all ye faithful and merch for Xmas presents.

If there's one thing we can all agree on in this country, it's that Xmas needs more sea shanties!

Only Te Upoko o te Ika show for 2025. New EP out in March 2026.

🎅🎅🎅

WELLINGTON SEA SHANTY SOCIETY

Aotearoa New Zealand's Most 'Sea Worthy' Shanty Group™ have been belting out traditional and original sea songs from Aotearoa, France, Spain, the UK and more, since time immemorial (2012).

The W.S.S.S have toured Aotearoa and France multiple times and are known for their rowdy and participatory live shows. They've performed at Paimpol (one of the world's largest shanty festivals), Splore, Albany Folk Festival (Aus), Quebec Sea Shanty Festival (Canada) and a shipload of other festivals in NZ, France & Canada. Their new EP 'Sea Shanties of the 70s, 80s, & Today!' has just recently surfaced to complement their 'Now That's What I Call Sea Shanties' series. Another must-listen is 'Ahoy!' - a French/English album made with Nantes amis Croche Dedans.

description:
Letters out Loud 2025 — Part of Friends of the Turnbull Library Public Programme Series, A 1940 newspaper exhorted its readers to ‘write a letter! Take a little chunk of your heart and spread it over some paper; it goes, oh, such a long way!’
Letters out Loud will expose some of those heart-felt issues people addressed on paper in the past. Well-known personalities will read letters from the Alexander Turnbull Library Collections which reveal concerns, among other things:
* the oldest extant Māori letter, written and read by a child
* the ups and downs of farm life
* Yehudi Menuhin in the bath
* a Member of Parliament in love
* on board the sinking Wahine in 1968.
Brought to life by familiar voices
Letters out Loud will be an evening of historical texts brought to life by familiar voices. Come and enjoy an enlivening of the past that has many resonances for today. Speakers include Ngahiwi Apanui- Barr, Una Cruickshank, Tanea Heke, Michele Leggott, David O’Donnell, Karen O’Leary, Trevor Richards, Vaughan Slinn, and Jennifer Ward-Lealand.
Doors open at 5pm for drinks and nibbles, readings begin at 6pm.
Book your tickets
Tickets to this gala fundraising event include a souvenir programme and refreshments.
https://events.humanitix.com/copy-of-letters-out-loud
All profits go to support grants for research at the Alexander Turnbull Library. The Friends of the Turnbull Library (FOTL) offer grants of $20,000 available to scholars whose research involves the use of the collections of the Alexander Turnbull Library.
https://turnbullfriends.org.nz/research-grant/
label: Community & Culture

description:
Ravel’s opera 'L'enfant et les sortilèges', New Zealand School of Music Classical Performance students present four performances Ravel's engagingly magical opera 'L'enfant et les sortilèges' at the Hannah Playhouse directed by Sara Brodie, conducted by Martin Riseley with the New Zealand School of Music orchestra.

Performed in French with subtitles, the show is suitable for all ages. The story involves a 'child' (L'enfant) whose awful behaviour brings an unexpected response: first the furniture rebels, the grandfather clock, the broken china cup, then the mathematics tutor and the Princess in the fairy tale book come to life, and eventually all the animals in the garden - squirrels, dragonfly, birds rise up - all of whom have good reason to 'teach the child a lesson'. It's a fabulous journey that we go on with the child who is confronted by all of these and indeed learns...

This is a project involving the whole of the Classical Performance programme: the voice students sing all the roles, each performing several roles, the NZSM orchestra will play for the performances, and the piano students are taking part as rehearsal pianists (répétiteurs) and playing in the orchestra.

Lighting design by Alex Fisher, set and costumes by Grace O’Brien, assistant director Theresa Hanaray, chorus master Kathryn Mosley, the show has been coordinated by NZSM Head of Classical Voice Jenny Wollerman in collaboration with the Toi Whakaari technical programme staff, graduates, and students
label: Music & Concerts

description:
50yrs Misuse of Drugs Act: What impact & what next?, The 1975 Misuse of Drugs Act (MoDA) has failed to deliver. Data from the United Nations Office for Drugs and Crime indicates the demand for drugs is greater than ever, while the supply of drugs knows no bounds. The failure and harm caused by the so called 'War on Drugs' is acknowledged globally and witnessed first hand here in Aotearoa New Zealand.

Back in 2011 a comprehensive review of the MoDA conducted by New Zealand Law Commission recommended the MoDA “should be repealed and replaced by a new Act …administered by the Ministry of Health”. HRCA wants to see that recommendation enacted.

New Zealand has a history for bold world leading policy reform: Woman’s Right to Vote; Decriminalisation of Sex Work; National Needle Exchange, Same Sex Marriage and most recently Drug Checking.

This half day Symposium will provide clear evidence why major law reform is necessary and detail the foundations upon which Aotearoa NZ can once again be innovative and lead the way with new drug laws based on evidence, research and experience -providing a safer environment for future generation.

Harm Reduction Coalition Aotearoa are delighted to have assembled a group of respected independent thinkers with vast experience of drug policy in Aotearoa and beyond, to reflect on the impact of the MoDA and to identify the principles and values needed to underpin new drug laws.

Warren Young: Prof. of Law & Former Deputy President New Zealand Law Commission.
Kirsten Gibson: Chair of Harm Reduction Coalition Aotearoa and Qualitative Researcher.
Fiona Hutton: Associate Prof. Institute of Criminology, Victoria University of Wellington.
Adam Dorsett: 40 yrs Living/Lived Experience of Prohibited Drug Use, 25yrs in Prison.
Julian Buchanan: Former UNODC Advisor and Criminology Professor.

NOTE:
This event is free and open to the public on a 'first come first served' basis.
However, eventfinda ticket holders will be guaranteed a seat.
label: Government & Politics

description:
Book Launch - Isaac Featherston 'Petatone': A Colonial Life, Join us next month to launch Isaac Featherston 'Petatone': A Colonial Life by John E Martin. The book will be launched by Charlotte MacDonald.

Tuesday 7 October, 6pm
Unity Books Wellington
All welcome!

'Existing views of Featherston are fragmentary, negative and not very satisfactory. He was the “little Doctor”, a single-minded despot wielding tyrannical power and casting an oppressive shadow. As I began to understand more of his life, I realised that there was little appreciation of a man who had contributed so much.’ —John E.Martin

Isaac Featherston was at the heart of some of the most significant developments in New Zealand from the 1840s colonisation by the New Zealand Company to the abolition of the provinces in 1876. A doctor, newspaper editor and politician, he advocated for the provinces against the domination of central government, while also being primarily responsible for the relocation of the capital from Auckland to Wellington in 1865.

Known amongst Māori as ‘Petatone’ and with a reputation for directness and honesty, he was at the very centre of Pākehā–Māori relations, and in his 1857 official portrait is depicted alongside leading rangatira Te Puni and Wi Tako.

About the author: Dr. John E. Martin has researched and written about New Zealand history since the 1980s, teaching in universities and employed as a historian in the public sector. He was parliamentary historian in the 2000s and 2010s. His publications include rural and labour history, the history of science and engineering, and social and political history. His books include The Forgotten Worker (1990), People, Politics and Power Stations (1991 and 1998), Holding the Balance (1996), The House: New Zealand’s House of Representatives, 1854–2004 (2004), Parliament’s Library (2008), Honouring the Contract (2010), Illuminating Our World (2017), A Colonist’s Gaze (2018) and most recently Empire City: Wellington Becomes the Capital of New Zealand (2022).
label: Government & Politics

Each day we'll have sixty+ unique stalls, loaded with self-made zines, comics, prints, and trinkets. Wellington Zinefest markets are free to attend, make sure you bring cash to buy zines tho!

description:
China and the Media Landscape in the Pacific, Over the last decade, the People’s Republic of China has sought to deepen its ties with Pacific Island countries. Beijing’s efforts to cultivate influence in the region have included expanding economic, diplomatic, and security ties with Pacific Island nations, as well as expanding China’s footprint in the region’s media landscape. This talk will present the findings of recent research on China’s efforts to shape reporting, media coverage and narratives in the Pacific Islands and put Beijing’s efforts within the context of the region’s rapidly evolving information landscape.
 About the speakers:
Heidi Holz is a Senior Research Scientist at CNA. For close to two decades, her work has focused on PRC strategic communications, propaganda, and influence efforts. She is a graduate of Georgetown University’s School of Foreign Service, where she received a master’s degree in security studies and a bachelor’s degree in Chinese and East Asian history.
Genevieve Collins is a research specialist in the China Studies program at CNA, where her research focuses on the behaviour of China’s state-run media and its reactions to US military operations and activities.
 Barbara Dreaver (Discussant) has been the Pacific Reporter for TVNZ 1 News since 2002, breaking stories uncovering social and economic issues affecting Pacific people living in New Zealand and the Pacific Islands. In 2020, she created a two-year training programme through Pacific Cooperation Broadcasting Ltd to support new Pacific journalists across the Pacific region. In the 2024 New Years Honours she was awarded an ONZM for services to investigative journalism and Pacific communities.
 About CNA: CNA is a non-profit, non-governmental research and analysis organization dedicated to providing independent and objective analyses to the U.S. government and the public. This talk will build on previous CNA research on China and the Pacific Islands media landscape which you can find at www.cna.org.

The house will be open 10am-4pm with entry by donation, including our current exhibition '75 Tinakori Road: 'This marvel had come to the lane".
From 10am plants from our garden raised by our wonderful volunteers will be sold as a fundraiser for Katherine Mansfield House & Garden. Plants priced from $5. Cash and card accepted, you may like to bring a box or bag to carry your plants home in.

description:
From Vision to Action, Wellingtonians have spoken. Thousands of voices have come together to help create A Vision for Wellington — a bold, pragmatic blueprint for our city’s future, backed by findings from independent research.
Now it’s time to hear how those who want to lead our city will respond.
We’ll begin with a short presentation of the Vision itself — celebrating the thousands of Wellingtonians who shaped it, and the bold blueprint they’ve helped create for our city’s future.
Then we’ll put the hottest issues on the table: like how to rebuild trust in leadership, how to get Wellington back in business and affordable again, and how to restore pride and energy to the heart of the city.
This is your chance to test the candidates’ ideas against a Vsion created by thousands of Wellingtonians — and to put your own questions to them as you decide your vote.
Harbourside Function Venue is located above Macs Brewery on the waterfront. Arrive from 5:00pm for a 5:30 start.
Free entry, registration essential. Spaces are limited.

description:
HRCA 50yrs Misuse of Drugs Act: What impact? What next?, Rutherford House (by the train station)
Room RHLT2
Bunny Street
Wellington
1.30-4.30pm
Free Admission
Light refreshments afterward
The NZ Misuse of Drugs Act 1975 (MoDA) has failed to deliver. Data from the United Nations Office for Drugs and Crime indicated the demand for drugs is greater than ever, while the supply of drugs knows no bounds.
A failure acknowledged globally and one we witness first hand here in Aotearoa NZ.
Back in 2011 a comprehensive review of the MoDA conducted by New Zealand Law Commission had already concluded the MoDA “should be repealed and replaced by a new Act …administered by the Ministry of Health”.
The Harm Reduction Coalition of Aotearoa wants to see that recommendation enacted.
We are delighted to have assembled a group of respected independent thinkers in the field, with vast experience of drug policy in Aotearoa and beyond, to reflect on the impact of the MoDA and to identify the principles and values needed to underpin new drug laws.
Warren Young
Professor of Law & Former Deputy President New Zealand Law Commission
Kirsten Gibson
Chair of Harm Reduction Coalition Aotearoa and Qualitative Researcher
Fiona Hutton
Associate Professor, Institute of Criminology, Victoria University of Wellington
Adam Dorsett
40 Years Living Experience of Prohibited Drug Use, in Prison for 25 years
Julian Buchanan
Former UNODC Advisor and Criminology Professor
New Zealand has a history for world leading innovative policy reform: Woman’s Right to Vote; Decriminalisation of Sex Work; National Needle Exchange, Same Sex Marriage and most recently Drug Checking.
This half day symposium will provide clear evidence why major law reform is necessary and detail the foundations upon which Aotearoa NZ can once again lead the way with new drug laws based on evidence, research and experience.
We look forward to seeing there!
Do pass on to anyone who might be interested.
label: Government & Politics

description:
C.W Stoneking NZ Tour, After an unforgettable run of shows across Aotearoa in January, acclaimed troubadour,
C.W. Stoneking makes his much-anticipated return this spring.

Presale 10am (NZST), Friday 15th August
General on sale 10am (NZST), Monday 18th August
Tickets from Banished Music
Register for presale at banishedmusic.com/subscribe

With his unmistakable swagger, Stoneking moves effortlessly between the red dust of Alice Springs and the deep grooves of the American South. Drawing on a heady blend of vintage blues, New Orleans jazz, gospel, calypso, country and western kitsch, he conjures a sound that is both timeless and thrillingly original.
Audiences can expect zombie shuffles, gospel stompers, and tropical torch songs – all delivered with wit, charm, and musical brilliance. Rich in character, darkly funny, and steeped in storytelling, Stoneking’s music may evoke a bygone era, but his performances crackle with electricity.

Spring Flowers In Watercolour - 2 Day Painting Workshop, Watercolour is an ideal medium for painting flowers using hard and soft edges to build the form of the petals. Tutor, Charlotte Hird, will demonstrate with beautiful bright colours and wet in wet technique for rich smooth backgrounds.

Charlotte uses an overhead camera projected onto a 55 inch TV for easy step by step instruction.

This workshop is for intermediate to advanced watercolour painters.

Bring your own watercolour paints, palette, brushes, and four Quarter sheets or four A3 sheets each of good quality 100% cotton 300gsm watercolour cold pressed or hot pressed paper.

One hour lunch - bring a packed lunch to have in our historic home or explore the local cafes in Te Aro.

description:
The Grand Kiki House of Marama Ball, General admission tickets have now sold out! Tickets for the community and walkers are still available
Whakatau mai ki tētahi pō whakataetae whakaari i te rerehua, ā-kākahu hoki e whakanui ana i te hunga takatāpui, hunga whakawāhine hoki, me te rerehua o te toi Ballroom.
Experience a night of performances, beauty, and fashion as walkers compete for trophies in a display of queer and trans joy, liberation, and Ballroom artistry.
Full events programme: https://tepapa.nz/MaramaBall
The Trailblazing Kiki House of Marama present The Grand Kiki House Of Marama Ball.
The Grand Kiki House of Marama Ball will celebrate five years of Marama excellence and the legacy of the growing Wellington Ballroom* scene.
With a fabulous line-up of categories, judges, commentators, and a DJ, including major local and international Ballroom figures, we invite you to wear your best outfits and prepare to finger snap, dance, and cheer the night away.
CATEGORIES AND THEMES:
Virgin Vogue – A Marama Storm (Treasure Chest)
Bizarre – Nocturnal Creatures of Folklore
Realness (Femme Queens, Trans Men, and Butch Queens) – Date Night Under the Moonlight
Hands Performance – Memoirs from Mother Marama
Body (Slim, Thicc and Luscious) – Heavenly Bodies
Butch Queen Vogue Fem – A Marama Storm (Pirates)
Face (Female Figures, Male Figures, and Gender Non-Conforming) – Beauty of the Blood Moon
OTA (Open to All) Best Dressed – Once in a Blue Moon
Commentator vs. Commentator – Echoes of the Moon
Femme Queen Performance – A Marama Storm (Mermaids)
OTA Runway – The Phases of Marama
House of the Night
JUDGES:
Icon Arturo Mulan (NYC Father of the House of Miyake-Mugler)
Legendary Overall Founding Mother Jaycee Iman
Trailblazing Founding Mother Ella Alexander
Legendary Founding Father Tamatoa Aitu
Founding Fatheir Fang Coven-Aucoin
COMMENTATORS:
Icon Tantine Matyouz Royalty (International Godmother of the House of Gorgeous Gucci)
Orijah Marama
DJ:
ATARANGI
BALLROOM COMMUNITY WALKERS & SPECTATORS TICKET ACCESS:
Contact the House of Marama on Instagram @houseofmarama or your local Ballroom leaders for the access codes to Ballroom Community Spectators & Walkers tickets.
There is a discount code that provides FREE access for Femme Queens who are not walking or competing. Contact us or your local leaders for the discount code.
The Grand Kiki House of Marama Ball is hosted by the Trailblazing Kiki House of Marama and proudly supported by OVĀ Collective and Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa.
This event is for adults only.
*BALLROOM
Ballroom is a subculture created in the late 1960s in Harlem, New York. Forged by Black and Latinx trans women and queer communities, it began as a protest against the racism they faced from White counterparts within the LGBTQIA+ community, as well as the transphobia and queerphobia they faced from mainstream society.
It is a space held to protect trans women of colour. Therefore, guests and participants of this culture alike must uphold respect and honour for this sacred space and those from which it came from. Homophobia, transphobia, or any discriminatory language and/or beliefs will not be tolerated. Remember to check your privilege at the door.
Learn more about the culture of Underground Ballroom on Google Arts and Culture.
Be sure to check out the growing Wellington Ballroom scene and community by following @houseofmarama and @ova_collective on Instagram.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Safeguarding week @ the Y, Join us to mark Child Safeguarding week!!!!

Every child deserves to be safe, and the Y strives to create strong, safe practice within our organisation. Today we are celebrating the importance of Safeguarding, and this year's theme of " Parenting in a digital world".
Kathryn Berkett, NZ renowned educational psychologist, will join us to speak about the effects of devices on the brain. We will release the newest version of " the Y way", our safeguarding expectations for Y staff working with children and young people, and will have the first viewing of our new, child friendly safeguarding video.

This is a great opportunity for those that work, live and interact with children and young people.

For more information email: safeguarding@ycentral.nz

description:
Native Plant Papermaking Kids Workshop, Native Plant Papermaking Kids Workshop
Do you know a child who loves craft and making a splash? Join us for a fun family papermaking session!

We’ll be getting our hands wet as we explore the creative world of handmade paper using native harakeke (NZ flax) pulp. You will start off learning the simple skills of how to form a sheet of paper from wet pulp, then develop these skills by making different shapes and sizes, such as sheets, cards, envelopes, and ornaments. Express your own flair by experimenting with bits and pieces to add different colours and textures to your creations.

This workshop is designed for kids and accompanying adults to enjoy together. Adults are expected to assist hands-on and join the fun. Ages 5 and up.

description:
Renaissance Gold - in celebration with Manawatū Sinfonia featuring Bach's Magnificat, Renaissance Gold - in celebration with Manawatū Sinfonia featuring Bach's Magnificat
On Saturday 13 September, at 7.00 pm in the Cathedral of the Holy Spirit on Broadway, PN, the choir under Christine Archer-Lockwood is to be joined by the Manawatu Sinfonia and soloists, Caroline Hickman, Jennifer Little and Lindsay Yeo with choristers Nigel Tongs and Bronté Hodgetts also singing solo in Bach's Magnificat. The Magnificat is a world favourite, arguably Bach's best choral piece that has transcended the ages, celebrating Luke's description of Mary's pregnancy.

In addition, the choir and orchestra perform Ritchie's Then I Understood. When a child of seven to nine, Laura Rangers sketched eight poems centred on summers at Otaki Beach, Ritchie seized the opportunity to add the musical dimension and the result are dual choirs - the Renaissance Singers split - accompanied by the Sinfonia to set off Rangers' delightful insights, so elegantly displayed. The magic that can be childhood.

The concert has a celebratory theme, it being the 50th anniversary of the choir. Thus the inclusion of Forrest's Three Nocturnes that express the wonderment involved when examining the heavens and the universe full of stars. Throughout this piece the percussionists alone from the Sinfonia provide whimsical accompaniment with a celeste providing the heavenly tones - a hit when played on the last occasion the choir sang the piece.

Opening the concert will be Carl Orff's O Fortuna from his popular Carmina Burana. While O Fortuna laments the role of fate it is set in the larger piece that celebrates life with gusto.

With the performers in great form (two choristers just back from singing with the world's best choir) this concert will no doubt build the sense of celebration - full of life and wonderment.

General Admission $25, Concession $20, Secondary School $15,
Under 13 Free.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Pumpkinhead - SLOTH 30th Anniversary Tour, Pumpkinhead - SLOTH 30th Anniversary Tour
Pumpkinhead celebrate the 30th anniversary of their critically acclaimed album Sloth this year, performing three exclusive never to be repeated reunion shows.

Sloth entered the New Zealand Album Charts on 30 April 1995, peaked at number 28 and stayed in the charts for 4 weeks. Their single “I Like” made it to number 16 in the Official Top 40 singles chart 10 March 1995.

“Now “Sloth”, Pumpkinhead’s debut album, compresses the quintet’s live energy into a head spinning whirlpool of fierce punky rock, powerful pop, and tempo-hopping Faith No More style metal. Not for the innocent!” – 4.5 stars – NZ HERALD 1995

“Sloth is the sound of a band that’s already found its feet, the sound of a band that’s played 500 gigs before recording their debut album. What we’ve got here is a classy, polished debut. “I Like” these songs a lot” – Kevin List – RIP IT UP 1995

description:
Water Cast Pendants Taster - Spring, This is a super quick 3-hour session, and is great fun to do with family or friends.

Water casting is a really hands-on low-tech casting method that results in surprising and fun little forms that can be turned into pendants with amazing textures and shapes.

You will be guided through melting silver and pouring it into water to create little charms.

Experiment with pouring at different heights to create different shapes.
Choose one or a few of your favourites to have drilled and turn into simple pendants or earrings, or new charms for your bracelets!

We will use hardened jump rings to attach your water-cast pieces to either colourful cord or you can choose sterling silver chains which you can purchase for extra.

The technique will be demonstrated with important health and safety practices, then students will be guided to do at least a couple of casts, and should expect to have at least one successful item to clean up and finish in the class.

A basic amount of metal allowance of a small amount of silver is included in your course costs, and if your projects go over that amount you can pay for the metal you use on the day via internet banking or cash.

This course is open to complete beginners and advanced makers. Extra materials such as chains and findings are available to purchase.

For health and safety reasons class participants must wear sturdy, closed toe shoes and have their hair tied back.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Putin’s Russia and Southeast Asia: The Kremlin’s Pivot to Asia and the Impact of the Russia-Ukraine War, Dr Ian Storey will discuss his new book on Russia’s relations with Southeast Asia. The first major study of Russia and Southeast Asia since the end of the Cold War, it traces the dramatic shifts in Moscow’s relations with the region since President Vladimir Putin took power in 2000. Dr Storey assesses the legacy of the Soviet Union, charts the evolution of Putin’s foreign policy and identifies the drivers behind the Kremlin’s ‘Turn to the East’ or Asia pivot. His book also examines Russia’s dialogue partnership with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the development of Moscow’s political, economic and military ties with each of the 11 regional states over the past 25 years. A large part of the book is devoted to Southeast Asia’s responses to Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. At the end of the talk Dr Storey will also provide an update of Russia-Southeast Asia relations in 2025 and how the region views the on-going Russia-Ukraine War.
Dr Ian Storey is a Senior Fellow at the ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute, Singapore. He specializes in regional security issues, focusing on Southeast Asia’s relations with the major powers and maritime security, especially the South China Sea dispute. Since joining ISEAS in 2007 he has been the editor of the ISEAS academic journal Contemporary Southeast Asia. Prior to ISEAS, Ian held academic positions at the Asia-Pacific Center for Security Studies, Hawaii and at Deakin University, Australia. Ian received his PhD from the City University of Hong Kong, his Master’s degree from the International University of Japan and his BA (Hons) from the University of Hull, England. He is the author of Putin’s Russia and Southeast Asia: The Kremlin’s Pivot to Asia and the Impact of the Russia-Ukraine War (2025) and Southeast Asia and the Rise of China: The Search for Security (2011)
label: Government & Politics

description:
Wellington Jazz Festival, Soul, funk, jazz, fusion, rhythm and blues — it’s a celebration of sound across the city this spring. The annual Wellington Jazz Festival is back. The event packs over 100 gigs into five days in venues around the city. 
The festival features two major international acts making exclusive New Zealand debuts. Wellington will see two-time Grammy Award-winning jazz vocalist and bandleader, Gregory Porter and five-time Grammy Award-winning jazz singer, Samara Joy. Gregory Porter’s unique and timeless sound blends jazz, soul, and gospel. His influences include Bakersfield Southern Gospel and jazz legend Nat King Cole. At just 25 years old, Samara Joy has become a breakout jazz sensation. She’s redefining 21st-century jazz with a rich, mature tone and refined phrasing. 
The treats in the programme continue with Australian First Nations soul singer Bumpy, and a commissioned work by New Zealand/Congolese drummer, composer, and rhythm master  Myele Manzanza. He’ll be performing with international supergroup, lvdf. The Rodger Fox Big Band returns with a tribute to Ray Charles, and the Aotearoa Jazz Orchestra has its inaugural performance with a Duke Ellington arrangement of Tchaikovsky’s The Nutcracker Suite. Many of the hospitality venues in Courtenay Place and its surrounding streets are planning intimate jazz gigs across the festival. Follow the sound of saxophones to find a spot to park up for the night.
label: Festivals

This is a call to all who believe in justice and human rights to join our hīkoi to Odlins Plaza for powerful speakers, solidarity stalls, and meaningful ways to take action. Our strength lies in Sumud [Palestinian steadfastness] and Kia Manawanui [Aotearoa’s perseverance.]

description:
The Challenges of Peacebuilding, In this conversation, Dr David Harland will reflect on his experience working as a mediator and negotiator in conflict zones and his role as Director of the Geneva-based Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue. The Centre was awarded the Carnegie Wateler Peace Prize in 2022 “for its track record of finding the means, including mediation, to bring parties together and end conflicts”. Its work has included involvement in Aceh and Mindanao, assisting with the disbanding of the Basque separatist group ETA, and the Black Sea Grain Initiative. David will share insights on the challenges of peacebuilding in an era of growing competition and contestation.
Dr David Harland is a former New Zealand diplomat and Executive Director of the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), a Geneva-based foundation that specialises in the mediation of armed conflict. He previously worked for the United Nations, including in Bosnia, Kosovo, Haiti and Timor Leste, and he wrote the UN Secretary-General’s landmark report on the fall of Srebrenica. David serves on the UN Secretary-General’s high-level advisory board on mediation. He has degrees from Harvard University, Tufts University, Beijing University and Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington.
The event will be followed by light refreshments.
label: Government & Politics

description:
Treasury Guest Lecture with Michael Keen: IN-PERSON attendance, Join us for our special Fiscal Policy for the Future seminar
New Zealand faces significant long-term fiscal challenges, including the rising costs associated with an ageing population, increasing demand for public services, and the need to adapt to a changing global economy. These pressures will require careful planning to ensure the sustainability of government finances while maintaining fairness and efficiency in the tax system.
Inland Revenue’s draft Long-Term Insights Briefing explores these issues by asking critical questions about the future shape and scale of our tax system. Similarly, the Treasury’s Long-Term Fiscal Statement highlights the importance of future-proofing our tax framework and other broader policy settings to address these challenges.
Join us for this seminar delivered by a highly regarded economist and expert in tax policy and administration, and a prolific author, Michael Keen, as he shares his insights on future proofing our tax system.
This will be a hybrid event, and we encourage you to attend it in person for an opportunity to engage in a discussion on all those issues with our guest speaker.
About this event
This will be a hybrid event. Please use this site to register if you plan to attend it in person.
If you would like to attend it virtually, please use THIS LINK to register.
The Tax Policy Charitable Trust has arranged Mick’s visit to New Zealand. The Trust was established to support leading tax policy thinking in New Zealand. You can read about the Trust’s work here.
About the presenter
Michael (Mick) Keen is a former Deputy Director of the Fiscal Affairs Department at the International Monetary Fund, where for over twenty years he played a central role in shaping and delivering IMF policies and advice on tax matters.
He has advised finance ministries in all parts of the world, including missions to over forty countries, and led the preparation of influential papers for the G20 and the Executive Board of the IMF.
Before joining the Fund, Mick was Professor of Economics at the universities of Essex (UK), Queens (Canada) and Kyoto, and is now Ushioda Fellow at the University of Tokyo.
Mick was the keynote speaker at the 2014 conference on the Future of Tax Administration in New Zealand and has provided peer review for Inland Revenue’s previous Long-Term Insights Briefing.
Mick has jointly authored, with Joel Slemrod, Rebellion, Rascals and Revenue – an entertaining account of how history illuminates the perennial challenges and timeless principles of taxation—and how the past holds clues to solving the tax problems of today.
About this seminar series
New ideas, innovative concepts, research evidence and expert advice are all crucial to stimulate and inform the Treasury’s economic analysis and advice. Our current theme for guest lectures - Fiscal Policy for the Future - explores the role of stabilising, sustainable and effective fiscal policy. Speakers provide insights into how fiscal policy can be designed to support government to meet its current and future objectives and obligations while adapting to changing circumstances and delivering value to the New Zealand public.
Fiscal policy has a stabilising role in helping to smooth the business cycle, while sustainability in fiscal policy is foundational for resilience to both shocks and longstanding challenges, such as climate change, technological advancements, and demographic trends. Ensuring effective and value for money expenditure is important so that fiscal policy contributes to the living standards of New Zealanders, both now and in the future.
Please note that the views, opinions, findings, and conclusions expressed in the Treasury Guest Lecture Series are those of the individual presenters. They do not necessarily reflect the views of the New Zealand Treasury or the New Zealand Government.
For updates and our latest research visit: www.treasury.govt.nz
Keep in touch
If you would like to be the first to hear about our upcoming events in the Treasury Guest Lecture Series, please SUBSCRIBE to stay up to date.
label: Government & Politics

We’re drafting an omnibus Reserve Management Plan to set out objectives, polices and rules that guide their use, management, protection and development and want your help. Tell us what you value about your favourite parks and reserves, what might impact their use, protection and enjoyment, and what ideas do you have for their future.

There's lots of ways to have your say - online, on paper and in person.

Come and chat to our Open Space Planning team

Saturday 30 August, 9am–1pm, Maclean Park, skatepark
Saturday 6 September, 9am–1pm, Waikanae Park, old skatepark

description:
Flying a tattered flag for New Zealand film: Rudall Hayward’s 60-year career, Flying a tattered flag for New Zealand film: Rudall Hayward’s 60-year career
In this month’s Friends of the Turnbull event, author and lecturer Annabel Cooper will talk about researching New Zealand filmmaker Rudall Hayward, best known for his silent films but also his later feature films ‘Rewi’s Last Stand’ and ‘To Love a Māori’.

Join us at the Library or online. Register if you’d like to join this talk and we'll send you the link to use on the day:

Rediscovering Rudall Hayward
Join us for a fascinating talk by historian and author Annabel Cooper as she delves into the life and legacy of Rudall Hayward — a trailblazer of New Zealand filmmaking.

Although not widely known today, Rudall’s career spanned from the early 1900s to the 1970s. He made four feature-length films during New Zealand’s silent film era, later navigating the financial challenges of accessing new sound equipment to make documentaries, educational films, and two more feature films — Rewi’s Last Stand (1940) and the first New Zealand film to be shot in colour, To Love a Māori (1972).

Drawing on research for her biography of Rudall Hayward and his family, Annabel Cooper will explore his enduring contributions to cinema, his collaborative work with his wives Hilda and Ramai, and the cultural legacy he left behind.

A Friends of the Turnbull Library event
The Friends of the Turnbull Library, Ngā Hoa o te Whare Pukapuka Turnbull, offers a monthly programme of free public talks. These talks are held in the National Library in Wellington and on Zoom. Some of these talks will be repeated in Auckland. The public programme highlights the work of researchers who draw on Turnbull material for their projects and staff who care for and research the collections.

About the speaker
Associate Professor Annabel Cooper taught at the University of Otago for 30 years, and published on a number of New Zealand topics including gender history and film. Her last book, Filming the Colonial Past: The New Zealand Wars on Screen, is the subject of an exhibition, He Riri Awatea: Filming the New Zealand Wars, curated with Ariana Tikao for the New Zealand Portrait Gallery and now showing at Canterbury Museum.
label: Film & Media

description:
Explore Monoprint Workshop, Of all the print making methods, mono printing is the most spontaneous, responsive and versatile, being the medium for everything from abstract expressionism to hyper photographic realism. Simple and direct with the minimum of equipment and media, mono printing is approachable for any age or ability level, yet the creative potential is unlimited.

Planned here is a three day workshop to introduce mono printing from simple hand printing, spontaneous transfer methods through to working with presses and multiple matrices.

For people starting in printmaking and people already with an art practice in any media. We will experiment with a whole new method of mark making, transfer and texture to build skill level and also provide a cross discipline change to invigorate your existing art practice of painting or drawing.

Also you will be introduced to a progressive evolution development technique for learning and to push yourself into new areas of creativity that can be applied to other art practices and medias.

One hour lunch - Bring a drink bottle and a packed lunch to enjoy in the historic Inverlochy house or explore the Te Aro cafes.

Basic materials are supplied.

Two day workshop: Sat 25 - Sun 26 October, 10 am - 4 pm daily.

description:
Country Boy/City Slicker: Callum Wagstaff and Oliver Pol, CALLUM WAGSTAFF: Hailing from the wilds of Normanby (population 1100), he will chew on bit of straw at any opportunity - a country boy through and through.
OLIVER POL: Pounding the mean streets and steep hills of Wellington all his life, somehow never becoming a civil servant, but a city slicker, nevertheless.
What will happen when their worlds collide? Will they fight to see if the country or city reigns supreme? No, they won’t. They’ll do a split-bill hour of standup comedy and it’ll be pretty fun.

Callum Wagstaff
A standout on the Aotearoa comedy circuit, known for his offbeat charm, punchy writing, and relentless gigging across the North Island. Originally from Taranaki, Callum has picked up multiple accolades, including Best Comedian three years running at the Comedy Hub Awards and Best Out-of-Towner at the Wellington Comedy Awards. With a distinctive comedic voice that turns the bizarre into brilliant, he’s an act with serious momentum.

“Callum’s awkward physicality and tales of shopping in Hawera have us doubled over.” - Theatreview

-Nominated Best Comedian Nelson Fringe 2024
-Runner-up, National Raw Comedy Quest 2022
 Oliver Pol
A youngish, tallish Wellingtonian standup who performs with an irrepressible, limb-flailing energy. 
As a natural overthinker with an interest in the most trivial corners of popular culture, Oliver combats his varied fears and insecurities by embracing the virtues of silliness. 
His comedy thrives on unusual observations and a sense of good-natured chaos.

description:
F*ck the Small Talk: Wellington #7, Sign up here: https://luma.com/ftstwellington7
F*ck the Small Talk has traveled the world from Berlin, Melbourne, London, Lisbon, and Mexico City, to Lisbon and is now coming to Wellington!

WHAT'S THIS ABOUT?
FTST is a one-of-a-kind social experience where strangers come together for an afternoon of meaningful, fun, and deep conversation. It’s also just a different & cool way of meeting new people by getting a bit out of your comfort zone and skipping the small talk!
Join us for games, talks, and connections with friends you haven’t met yet. Join if you get annoyed after being asked what you do, where you are from, and how long you have been in Wellington every single time you meet someone. If you feel that there are better questions in life then this is the place for you.

HOW DOES IT WORK?
We start with a short & sweet intro talk followed by a few light-hearted group games to warm up. Don't worry, nothing too awkward! After that, we split you up into small groups and start with the conversation rounds (with 3-4 people). We'll have awesome question cards that will guide the flow of the conversation. You’ll never have to speak in public if you don’t want to!

HOW TO JOIN?
Take 2 minutes to fill out our form

https://luma.com/ftstwellington7
Our events are limited to 30 handpicked guests to ensure a cozy atmosphere. We prioritize a balance in gender and cultural diversity, making each gathering a unique blend of perspectives! If you're invited you'll receive an invite with a special link via our ticketing platform Luma

HOW MUCH IS IT?
The cost to attend is NZD 23 (early llama) - NZD 25 (general llama) and includes the following:
3 hours of facilitated and curated activities
Light snacks to keep the energy going (only if outdoors)
A space to meet new people in the least boring way possible
Supporting our mission to slowly eliminate small talk around the world
Also includes those pesky ticket fees!

WHERE IS IT?
We host our events in awesome cafes, rooftops, and bars across the city. We only reveal the location to ticket holders 24 hours before the event.

WHAT THEY SAY
“Great way to connect with people in a more meaningful way. Get to the heart of the matter, dive straight into what really counts!” - Matthias

“This is the kind of activity humanity needs every weekend. Thank you for all.” - Sonya

“F*ck the Small Talk changes the narrative from "Where are you from?" to "When was the last time you laughed uncontrollably?" and I think that's beautiful.” - Monika

“I loved F*ck the small talk, I was a little bit nervous at first but they are pros at making you feel comfortable with the rest of the group, the activities are really fun and I enjoyed every second (consider that the one who's saying this is very, very shy). Give it a try!” - Brenda

"it’s a wonderful experience, it’s like being a kid again, when you were at the park, playing with other kids, and just decided you were going to be best friends for the next hours. Maybe you’ll never see those kids again. But that hour was amazing because you both opened up and trusted each other." - Sara

“Lively, interesting, introspective, completely open and no judgement. Everyone that joined was ready for great conversation and helped with different perspectives. So much fun! I can't wait for the next one! “ - Yaz

Check out our 100+ Google reviews: https://goo.gl/maps/TpZy77bfPFkGoikn7

FAQ
• Can I come alone?
Of course, in fact, we encourage it! 99% of people do.

• I signed up but never got an invite. Why?
We usually get a high volume of sign-ups yet we like to keep it cozy & only about 30 people. We believe this is a good number to ensure an awesome experience! Please try again next time if do not receive an invite - no hard feelings

• Why do you charge?
We value our time and put a lot of love, planning, and effort into creating & designing these experiences.
This is our project/business and what we give to the world and we think everything should be a fair exchange! However, money should never be the reason for people not to attend. If you can’t afford it simply get in touch with us

• I'm digging this! Can I get involved somehow?
Sure thing, send us a message!

• Can I bring my cute dog/llama?
It depends on where the event is! Message us to make sure. But it's always a YES in our hearts.

• Can I get a refund if I can't make it?
Unfortunately, we do not offer refunds or ticket transfers to another event date if you cannot attend with a notice of less than 5 days notice. BUTTTT feel free to pass on your ticket to a friend, provided they also sign up for the form
--

𝘾𝙤𝙢𝙚 𝙘𝙪𝙧𝙞𝙤𝙪𝙨, 𝙡𝙚𝙖𝙫𝙚 𝙘𝙤𝙣𝙣𝙚𝙘𝙩𝙚𝙙.
* Only 30 spots available
* Location is only revealed to ticket holders!
* Age guide, 22-40 years old (only a reference, never a limit
)

This event is a no-phone experience. Keep them tucked in your pocket

We started in Berlin back in 2019 out our frustration of being asked 'where are you from?' 40 times in one week. Now there are chapters in 11 cities around the world including Mexico City, Zurich, Lisbon, London, Berlin and Vancouver.

--
Stay in touch
Website: https://www.epicllama.com/fuckthesmalltalk
Instagram: www.instagram.com/epic.llama/
Join the club (newsletter): epicllama.myflodesk.com/wellington
label: Hobbies & Interests

description:
Men's Circle: Reclaiming Connection, Men's Circle: Reclaiming Connection
The Men’s Circle is a free, supportive gathering for men to connect, share openly, and grow together. Whether you're navigating life changes, seeking community, or simply wanting a space to be heard, you're welcome here.
Expect honest conversations and the kind of connection that’s rare but necessary. No pressure to speak—just your presence is enough. We follow a respectful, non-judgmental format that prioritizes safety, confidentiality, and authenticity.
Optional Plant-Based Dinner
Stay afterwards for a nourishing, plant-based dinner and dessert ($15). Sharing a meal is a powerful way to extend the connection beyond the circle. This gathering is not run for profit—Andre is simply passionate about creating spaces for genuine connection.
What to Expect in the Circle:
Gathering in Circle: We sit in a circle to foster a sense of unity and equality.
Centering In: A short meditation or silence helps us arrive and ground.
Talking Object: A shared object moves around—only the person holding it speaks.
Optional Sharing: Speak if you feel moved. You’re always welcome to pass.
Active Listening: No interruptions, advice, or feedback—just presence.
Confidentiality: What's shared in the circle, stays in the circle.
Our Shared Agreements:
Speak from the “I”: Share from your own experience, not on behalf of others.
No fixing or judging: This is not a space to solve, but to witness.
Be present: Share what’s alive for you right now.
Respect and trust: We uphold a culture of care, confidentiality, and non-judgment.
Meet Andre, your host
Andre has been immersed in men’s work since the age of 13, when he first experienced a rite of passage in Golden Bay. That formative experience sparked a lifelong connection to circle work, which he later deepened by returning as a mentor. Over the years, Andre has come to value the power of sitting in circle—of men coming together in honesty, vulnerability, and presence to witness and support one another. A multi-instrumental musician, poet, and pranayama (breathwork) facilitator, Andre also brings his passion for ecstatic dance, philosophy, and authentic connection into his offerings. He is deeply inspired by the question of what it means to be human—how we can more fully experience our aliveness, our depth, and reconnecting with the beauty of life together.
